BETWEEN

ABCLIMITED(Registered in England No.) whose registered office is at ("ABC"); and

XYZLIMITED(Registered inScotlandNo.)whose registered office is at ("Contractor").

BACKGROUND

At the date of the AgreementABCoperates two separate divisions within its business. The first being sweet treats ("Treats") and the second, groceries ("Groceries").

The warehousing requirements in relation to Treats isat the date of the Agreementoperated in-house byABCat its warehouse inTown.

The warehousing requirements in relation to Groceries isat the date of theAgreement splitbetween two 3PLs. The first isGB, operating from its warehouse inCityand the second isW, operating from its warehouse inCity.

ABCwishes to consolidate and outsource its warehousing requirements for both Treats and Groceries to a single 3PL at one national distribution centre.

This consolidation of warehousing will necessitate a staggered phasing in of Treats and Groceries into the national distribution centre to account for the different expiry dates ofABCagreements withGBand W. Service provision by the Contractor will therefore be phased accordingly.

The Contractor has agreed to provide toABCwarehouse services on the provisions set out in this Agreement.

Drafting Conventions

The headings in this Agreement are inserted for convenience only and shall not affect the interpretation or construction of this Agreement.

Words expressed in the singular shall include the plural and vice versa. Words referring to a particular gender include every gender. References to a person include an individual, company, body corporate, corporation, unincorporated association, firm, partnership or other legal entity.

The words"other","including"and"in particular"shall not limit the generality of any preceding words or be construed as being limited to the same class as any preceding words where a wider construction is possible.

References to any statute or statutory provision shall include (i) any subordinate legislation made under it, (ii) any provision which it has modified or re-enacted (whether with or without modification), and (iii) any provision which subsequently supersedes it or re-enacts it (whether with or without modification) whether made before or after the date of this Agreement.

All references in this Agreement to Clauses,Schedulesand Appendicesare to the clauses,schedulesand appendicesto this Agreement unless otherwise stated.

This Agreement sets out the terms on which the Contractor shall provide the Services.The provision of the Services shall be subject to this Agreement to the exclusion of all other terms and conditions that the Contractor seeks to impose or incorporate, or which are implied by trade, customer, practice, course of dealing or otherwise.

Appointment

ABC, for itself and on behalf of the members of theABCGroup, appoints the Contractor to:

with effect from the dates set out in Schedule8(Transition Services), provide the relevant Transition Services relating to theTownOperation,CityOperation andTownOperation(as applicable);

from therelevant Service Commencement Dates(as set out in Schedule8(Transition Services)and Schedule 17 (TownServices) (as applicable)), provide those elements of the services transferred from theTownOperation,CityOperation andTownOperation under the Transition Services, in accordance with this Agreement, asServices;

with effect from theTownServices Commencement Date, provide theTownServices for theTownServices Period.

With effect fromthe Full Service Commencement Datethe purchase of the Services byABCfrom the Contractor for the benefit of it and the members of its Group is exclusive and, save as otherwise stated under this Agreement,ABCshall not purchase the Services from another supplierduring the termof this Agreement (except thatABCmay purchase Services, or services similar in part or all to the Services, from another supplier in the 12 months period before this Agreementcs or expiresprovidedABChas demonstrated to the Contractor an intention to have the Services or services similar in part or all to the Services provided from a location or locations other than the Principal Warehouse before such purchase of Services, and the use of another supplier is part of that transition; and that if another supplier is providing the Services that the Management Fee earned by the Contractor in the 12 months period before this Agreement terminates or expires does not fall more than 0% below the level of the Management Fee earned by the Contractor in the 12 months prior to the appointment of another supplier). IfABCdoes purchase Services, or services similar in part or all to the Services, then it shall be dealt with in accordance with the Change Control Procedure.

Unless expressly stated otherwiseABCis not subject to any minimum value or purchasing requirement under this Agreement.

Commencement andDuration

This Agreement shall be deemed to have come into force on the Commencement Date and shall (subject toClause3.3andtheotherprovisions for earlier termination set out in this Agreement) continue in force for 10 years from theFullService Commencement Date ("Initial Period").The parties may agree terms to extend this Agreement past the Initial Period, but if such terms are not agreed this Agreement shall automatically terminate on the expiration of the Initial Period.

Block A Vacant Possession

If the Block A Vacant Possession Notice has not been served pursuant to the Agreement for Lease on the Contractor (and a copy subsequently provided toABC) by1March 2017, then within five (5) Business Days thereafter (provided the Block A Vacant Possession Notice has still not been served on the Contractor)ABCmay serve notice on the Contractorto terminate this Agreement and upon service of such notice this Agreement shall terminate but without prejudice to the liability of either party in respect of any antecedent breach (but without liability for any compensation or damages resulting solely from such termination, including pursuant to Schedule 16 (Termination Compensation and Consequences)).

Transition

During the Transition Period the Contractor shall carry out the Transition Services in accordance with the Transition Plan.

If the obligations in the Transition Plan are not met in accordance with the timescales set outin the Transition Plan then:

if such obligations are not met directly as a result of afailure byABCto comply with its obligations under this Agreement,the Contractor shall be entitled to relief from its obligations to the extent that the Contractor has been unable to fulfil its obligations under this Agreement as a consequence ofsuchABC'failureandABCshall bear the properly and reasonably incurred unavoidable costs of the Contractor, which have beenreasonably and necessarily incurred in accordance with this Agreementarising directly from the delay caused byABC; or

if such obligations are not met as a result of an act or omission of the Contractor, the Contractor shall use all reasonable endeavours to remedy such failure(s);

if such obligations are not met and neither party is at fault:

the Contractor shall continue to comply with its obligations to provide the Services to the extent that it is able in accordance with the Agreement;and

the parties shall use all reasonable endeavours to discuss in good faith alternative arrangements or changes satisfactory toABCto remedy the delay.If the parties fail to agree any alternative arrangements or changes then, if the relevant obligationsin the Transition Planhave notbeen fulfilled and thereforeFullService Commencement Datehas not occurred beforethe Longstop Date,ABCshall be entitled to terminate the Agreement in accordance with Clause4.3.

If the obligations in the Transition Planhave not been fulfilled and therefore Full Service Commencement Date has not occurred beforetheLongstopDate thenABCmay terminate this Agreement on 28 days' notice in writing and shall, in the circumstances specified in Schedule 16 (Termination Compensation and Consequences) comply with its obligations set out in Schedule 16 (Termination Compensation and Consequences).

Provision of Services

Following the Commencement Date and during the term of this Agreement the Contractor shall:

provide the relevant Transition Services until the relevant Service CommencementDateor such longer period as is required pursuant to Clause4;

provide the Services (and procure that the Personnel, the subcontractors (if any) and its subcontractors personnel shall provide the Services)from the relevant Service Commencement Date until the Termination Date, or in respect of theTownServices for theTownServices Period,:

in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement and in particular, the Service Levels and Schedule 1 (The Services)and, in respect of theTownServices, Schedule17(TownServices);

using reasonable skill and care;

in accordance with Good Industry Practice;

in accordance with all Applicable Laws (including the Modern Slavery Act); and

in accordance with the Policies.

comply with its obligations set out in Schedule 15(Continuous Improvement);

use all reasonable endeavours to achieve economies of scale and cost savings through the provision of services similar to the Services to other customers of the Contractor;

co-operate withABCand any third party (including Carriers) engaged to provide services toABC, including a third party which is a competitor of the Contractor, so as to integrate (where reasonably required byABC) other services, materials or equipment supplied byABCor any third party with the Services. Such co-operation shall include, where appropriate, the provision of information and provision of access to the Contractors operations.

to provide the Contractor Equipment, Contractor Systems and all other equipment, Personnel and materials necessary to provide the Services;

provide the Services efficiently with the optimum use of all resources so as to provide the Services at the lowest reasonably obtainable overall cost and to actively seek ways of reducing costs;

comply with the safety and security standards and site procedures and codes ofABCin force from time to time;

comply with any reasonable instructions and guidelines issued byABCfrom time to time;

comply with the all applicablestandards and guidelines relating to the Services (including obtaining and maintaining the relevant accreditations such as maintaining and complying with a recognised quality management system certified to ISO 9001:2008 standard or equivalent for the Services) and shall provide such supporting evidence of such compliance as is reasonably requested byABC;

to informABCpromptly, giving details of the circumstances, reasons and likely duration, in the event it becomes aware of anything of whatsoever nature and whether or not the result of any act or omission on the part of the Contractor or its Personnel or sub-contractors which may prevent the Contractor fulfilling its obligations in accordance with this Agreement including immediately sending toABCa copy of every notice or other communication relating to the provision of the Services received from or sent to any person or body concerning health and safety, environmental, and regulatory matters, the fulfilment of the Exit Plan or the performance of the Transition Services or theServices;

supply the Services in such a manner as not to prevent or in any way restrictABCfrom carrying on its business and so as to cause the minimum of disruption or interference with the interests or activities ofABC. Service Levels

The Contractor shall ensure that the Services meet or exceed the relevant Service Levels with effect from the relevant Service Commencement Date.

The Contractor shall monitor performance against the Service Levels and report its performance in accordance with Schedule 4 (Contract Management and Reporting).

If there is a Service Failure, the Contractor shall promptly:

  1. notifyABCof the Service Failure in accordance with Schedule4(Contract Management, Information & Reporting),Schedule 3 (Service Levels)and Schedule 17 (TownServices) in respect of the Service Levels applicable to theTownServices;
  2. (and in any event within 3 (three) Business Days of becoming aware of a Service Failure) provideABCwith a remediation plan forABC' approval;
  3. deploy all additional resources and take all remedial action that is reasonably necessary to rectify or to prevent the Service Failure(s) from reoccurring; and
  4. carry out the actions identified in the agreed remediation plan in accordance with its terms.

On the occurrence of a Material Service Level Breach, the Contractor shall:

  1. as soon as practicable and in any event within 3 (three) Business days from the point at which the Contractor becomes aware of the Material Service Level Breach, provideABCwith a remediation plan in respect of the Material Service Level Breach forABC' approval and obtainABC' approval to such plan;
  2. as soon as practicable and in any event within 10 (ten) Business Days of obtainingABC' approval to the remediation plan (or such other period as the parties may agree,acting reasonably) ("Final Remediation Period") carry out the actions identified in the agreed remediation plan toABC' reasonable satisfaction; and
  3. deploy all additional resources and take all other remedial action that is reasonably necessary to rectify or to prevent the Material Service Level Breach from reoccurring.

If, following the occurrence of a Material Service Level Breach, the Contractor fails to complete the actions referred to in Clause6.4in respect of that Material Service Level Breach within the Final Remediation Period toABC' reasonable satisfaction,ABCmay, on written notice,and without prejudice to its rights to terminate the Agreement in accordance with Schedule 2 (Service Levels),terminate part or all of the Services with immediate effect.

If a Material Service Level Breach that has been remedied in accordance with Clause6.4reoccurs within the 12 (twelve) month period following the expiry of the relevant Final Remediation Period,ABCmay, on written notice, terminate part or all of the Services with immediate effect.

The parties shall review the Service Levels on an annual basis in accordance with Schedule 3 (Service Levels)and Schedule 17 (TownServices) in respect of the Service Levels applicable to theTownServices,to ensure that they accurately and comprehensively reflect class leading performance.

Any Products lost by the Contractor which are subsequently located but which then cannot be sold byABCdue to insufficient residual shelf life, rotation issues, customer refusals or discontinuation of the Product in the marketplace, shall be treated as a Stock Loss for the purposes of Clauses11.8to11.11(inclusive).

Amendments to Agreement and Change Request Form

For the purposes of this Agreement a"Change Request"is:

  1. a request to change or add to the Services;
  2. to amend this Agreement or any document attached to or referred to in this Agreement (including any specification); or
  3. any matter which causes or is likely to causeABCto incur costs or charges outside the scope of the Charges.

Subject to Clause16.6no Change Request shall be binding on the parties unless the requirements of this Clause16have been satisfied and a Change Request Form is agreed and signed by the Authorised Representatives.

Subject to Clause16.6the parties shall, until such time as a Change Request is formally agreed to by both parties, continue to perform their respective obligations without taking account of the Change Request.

Change Requests may be originated either byABCor by the Contractor or may be originated by the parties jointly. In the case of any Change Request, the Contractor shall within ten (10) Business Days supply toABCeither:

  1. full details of all consequential changes which will be required to the Services, the Service Levels, the Charges and all other effects of the proposed change which must be reasonable and demonstrable toABC; or
  2. written confirmation that there will be no such consequential changes or effects;

the"Change Request Report".

In the event the Contractor gives notice toABCwithin five (5) Business Days of receipt of a Change Request that it cannot provide the Change Request Report within such ten (10) Business Day period, the parties shall agree a suitable period within which the Contractor shall be required to provide the Change Request Report. If the parties are unable to agree such extension to the time-table within five (5) Business Days of receipt byABCof such notice from the Contractor, then the matter shall be referred for determination in accordance with the Dispute Resolution Procedure.

The parties shall use all reasonable endeavours to agree a Change Request within ten (10) Business Days of receipt of the Change Request Report byABCbut if they are unable to reach agreement, the following provisions shall apply:

if a Change Request originated by the Contractor would inABCs reasonable opinion have an adverse impact on the Contractors ability to perform the Services in accordance with the Service Levels,ABCshall be entitled to refuse that Change Request;

if the Contractor can demonstrate toABCs reasonable satisfaction that a Change Request originated byABCwould require any consequential changes as set out in Clause16.4(a) (including reasonable changes to the Service Charges),ABCshall be entitled to require the Contractor to comply with that Change Request subject toABCagreeing to such consequential changes;

if theContractorfails to demonstrate toABCs reasonable satisfaction that any consequential changes as set out in Clause16.4(a) are required,ABCshall be entitled to require the Contractor to comply with that Change Request; and

in all othercircumstances(including where a dispute arises as to whether any requirement ofABCor the Contractor is a Change Request) the dispute shall be referred for determination in accordance with the Dispute Resolution Procedure.

As soon as the Contractor orABCbecomes aware of any change that should be made to the Services to ensure that the Services and the performance of them conform to any change of legislation, Good Industry Practice or new legal or regulatory requirements which affects the Services, the Contractor or Customer shall notify the other party of the change and, unless otherwise instructed byABC, the Contractor shall carry out the change as part of the Services at no charge toABC.

On signature by the Authorised Representatives of a Change Request Form, this Agreement shall be deemed amended in accordance with the provisions of that Change Request Form.

If:

the Contractor holdsABCData on the Contractor Systems; and

BUSINESS CONTINUITY AND Force Majeure

TheexampleBusiness Continuity Plan is set out in Schedule 10 (Business Continuity Plan)and in respect of IT disaster recovery is set out in Appendix 5 to Schedule 9 (IT and IT Interface Specification)("Example Business Continuity Plan"). The Contractor shall develop the Business Continuity Planto the reasonable satisfaction ofABC(and in at least equivalent level of detail to the Example Business Continuity Plan)and submit such plan toABCfor approvalas required byABCduring the period prior to 31 May 2017. The Contractor shall make such amendments to the Business Continuity Plan asABCmay reasonably require following each submission of the Business Continuity Plan within fourteen (14) days of receiving notificationfromABCof the required amendments or by such earlier date as is required in order for the Business Continuity Plan to be in a form satisfactory toABCby 31 May 2017.

The Contractor shall maintain the Business Continuity Plan. The Contractor shall not amend the Business Continuity Plan withoutABC's consent (not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed). The Contractor shall comply with its obligations in the Business Continuity Plan and Schedule 10 (Business Continuity Plan) and shall implement the Business Continuity Plan in accordance with Schedule 10 (Business Continuity Plan).

A party will not be in breach of this Agreement nor liable for any failure or delay in performance of any obligations under this Agreement (and the date for performance of the obligations affected will be extended accordingly) as a result of Force Majeure, provided that such party complies with the obligations set out in this Clause25and the Business Continuity Plan.Save as provided in Clause25.10,a Force Majeure will not entitle either party to terminate this Agreement.

The Contractor shall implement immediately the Business Continuity Plan on becoming aware of a Force Majeure taking place or reasonably expected to take place.

The party affected by Force Majeure shall immediately notify the other in writing of the matters constituting the Force Majeure and shall keep that party fully informed of their continuance and of any relevant change of circumstances whilst such Force Majeure continues.

The party affected by Force Majeure shall take all reasonable steps available to it to minimise its effects on the performance of its obligations under this Agreement.

ABCis entitled to suspend its own performance of this Agreement including payment during such period in which the Contractor is affected by a Force Majeure without liability to the Contractor.

The Contractor shall not be entitled to payment fromABCin respect of extra costs and expenses incurred by virtue of the Force Majeureunless such extra costs have been agreed in advance in writing byABC.

If an event of Force Majeure results in the suspension of the Services, then if the Contractor is the affected partyABCshallonly be obliged to pay the Contractor Charges if and to the extent that the Contractor has necessarily and reasonably incurred costs in trying to carry out the Services.

If Force Majeure continues for longer than 5 (five) Business Days,ABCmay, whilst the Force Majeure continues, terminate this Agreement on notice in writing to the Contractor.

(the"Step In Notice").

the Contractor shall give all reasonable assistance toABC(or third party appointed byABC) while it (or the third party appointed byABC) is taking the Required Action.

the Contractor shall be relieved of its obligations to provide such part of the Service; and

in respect of the period in whichABCis taking Required Action, the Charges due fromABCto the Contractor shall equal the amount the Contractor would receive if it were satisfying all its obligations and providing the Services affected by the Required Action in full over that period less and amount equal toABC' costs of taking the Required Action.

ABCshall give the Contractor not less than twenty (20) Business Days written notice of the cessation of the Required Action.

The Contractor shall bear its own costs in connection with any step-in byABCunder this Clause29and any costs incurred byABCin taking any Required Action (including any third party costs).

The waiver by either party of any breach of this Agreement shall not prevent the subsequentenforcement of that provision and shall not be deemed to be a waiver of any subsequent breach of that or any other provision.

Dispute Resolution Procedure

If a dispute arises out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance, validity or enforceability of it, then:

either party may call a meeting of the parties by giving not less than 15 Business Days' written notice to the other, and each party shall procure that an authorised representative attends all such meetingsor require the dispute to be in the agenda of the next quarterly strategic meeting to be held in accordance with Schedule 4 (Contract Management, Information and Reporting);

those attending the relevant meeting shall use all reasonable endeavours to resolve the dispute. If the meeting fails to resolve the dispute within15 days of its being referred to it, either party may refer the dispute to (in the case ofABC) the Head of Procurement ofABCand in the case of the Contractor the Chief Executive of the Contractor by notice in writing, who shall use reasonable endeavours to resolve the dispute as amicably as possible within 15 days of the dispute being referred tothem;

if the Parties fail pursuant to Clause37.1(b)to resolve the dispute in the allotted time the parties may within that period agree in writing to enter into an alternative dispute resolution procedure with the assistance of amediator agreed by the parties or, in default of such agreement, appointed by the Centre for Effective Dispute Resolution, 70 Fleet Street, London EC4Y 1EU and shall attempt to settle the dispute in accordance with the CEDR Model Mediation Procedure; and

if the parties reach a settlement, such settlement shall be reduced to writing and, once signed by a duly authorised representative of each of the parties, shall be and remain binding on the parties.

The procedure in this Clause37shall be binding on the parties with regard to participation in the mediation but not as to its outcome. All negotiations connected with the dispute shall be conducted in strict confidence and without prejudice to the rights of the parties in any future legal proceedings.

if the Parties fail pursuant to Clause 37.1 to resolve the dispute in the allotted time then after 40 Business Days after the referral of the dispute to a mediator either party may refer the dispute to an Expert parties appointed in accordance with and subject to the process set out in sub-paragraphs37.3 (a) to (k) below (inclusive).

The parties shall agree on the appointment of an independent Expert and shall agree with the Expert the terms of their appointment.

If the parties are unable to agree on an Expert or the terms of their appointment within seven days of either party serving details of a suggested expert on the other, either party shall then be entitled to request The Institute of Chartered Accountants of England and Wales to appoint an Expert of repute and experience in relation to the subject matter and nature of the dispute and this Agreement and for The Institute of Chartered Accountants of England and Wales to agree with the Expert the terms of appointment.

The Expert is required to prepare a written decision including reasons and give notice (including a copy) of the decision to the parties within a maximum of three months of the matter being referred to the Expert.

If the Expert dies or becomes unwilling or incapable of acting, or does not deliver the decision within the time required by this clause then:

either party may apply to The Institute of Chartered Accountants of England and Wales to discharge the Expert and to appoint a replacement Expert with the required expertise; and

this clause shall apply to the new Expert as if they were the first Expert appointed.

All matters under this clause must be conducted, and the Experts decision shall be written, in the English language.

The parties are entitled to make submissions to the Expert and will provide (or procure that others provide) the Expert with such assistance and documents as the Expert reasonably requires for the purpose of reaching a decision.

To the extent not provided for by this clause, the Expert may in their reasonable discretion determine such other procedures to assist with the conduct of the determination as they consider just or appropriate including (to the extent considered necessary) instructing professional advisers to assist them in reaching their determination.

Each party shall with reasonable promptness supply each other with all information and give each other access to all documentation and personnel and/or things as the other party may reasonably require to make a submission under this clause.

The Expert shall act as an expert and not as an arbitrator. The Expert shall determine the relevant dispute which may include any issue involving the interpretation of any provision of this Agreement, their jurisdiction to determine the matters and issues referred to them and/or their terms of reference. The Expert may award interest as part of their decision. The Experts written decision on the matters referred to them shall be final and binding on the parties in the absence of manifest error or fraud.

All matters concerning the process and result of the determination by the Expert shall be kept confidential among the parties and the Expert.

Each party shall act reasonably and co-operate to give effect to the provisions of this clause and otherwise do nothing to hinder or prevent the Expert from reaching their determination.

The parties shall bear their own legal costs of complying with Clauses37.1 and 37.2, but the costs and expenses ofreference to an Expertshall be borne by the parties equally.

Notwithstanding the provisions of this Clause37, either party may take proceedings or seek remedies before the courts or any competent authority of any country for interim or interlocutory remedies in relation to any breach of this Agreement or infringement by the other party of that partys Intellectual Property Rights.

Law

This Agreement and any issues, disputes or claims arising out of or in connection with it (whether contractual or non-contractual in nature such as claims in tort, from breach of statute or regulation or otherwise) shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of England and Wales.

Jurisdiction

Subject to first complying with Clause37(Dispute Resolution Procedure), all disputes or claims arising out of or relating to this Agreement shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English and Welsh Courts to which the parties irrevocably submit.

Schedule 1

The Services

WAREHOUSE OPERATIONAL SPECIFICATION

The activities listed below are included as part of the'core warehouse solution forABC.

The Contractor's performance will be monitored on a continual basis against agreed performance measures. In additionABCreserves the right to monitor the Contractor's performance against any of the warehousing requirements and standards listed below.

TRANSITION

The parties acknowledge that there is a transitional period during which the Contractor will carry out Transition Services (in accordance with Schedule 8 (Transition) and that the Contractor shall be required to provide Services in accordance with this Schedule with effect from the relevant Service Commencement Date as set out in Schedule 8 (Transition).

The Transitional Services anticipate that part of the Principal Warehouse shall be used to provide Transitional Services prior to the Full Service Commencement Date. The provisions of this Agreement shall apply to the Transitional Services provided at the Principal Warehouse as if they were Services (save for the exclusivity obligation onABCset out at Clause2.2and paragraph 3 below), except to the extent amended by Schedule 8 or otherwise agreed by the parties.

WAREHOUSE REQUIREMENTS

With effect fromFull Service Commencement Datethe Contractor shall provide warehousing services as set out in this Agreement for all ofABCUK(excluding international/export)warehouse requirements for ambient manufactured Product:

Except as anticipated under Schedule 8 (Transition)

And except for and excluding Out of Scope Services.

The Principal Warehouse shall comply with the minimum requirements set out in this Schedule 1,ABCCode of Practice for Warehousing and Distribution (vC0Po57) ("Global Standard") and the BRC Global Standard for Storage and Distribution ("BRC Standard") (as such standards are updated from time to time). The Warehouse shall hold industry standard accreditations including British Retail ConsortiumandASI Food Safety.

OPERATING REQUIREMENTS

The operating requirements are defined by a combination ofABCSBU requirements,ABC'scustomer order requirements and the need to minimise the operating costs incurred in the warehouse operation.

Standards: The Contractor shall ensure that it performs the Services in accordance with:

The Policies

The Global Standards

The BRC Standard

TheABCHealth and Safety Procedures Sections 4.3, 1.6, General Rules and Conditions for Contractors (Revision 3) (as updated from time to time) ("H&S Standard")

Health and Safety Executive Warehousing and Storage, A guide to health and safety (HSG76 (as updated from time to time) ("HSE Guidance").

ABCCode of Practice- Finished Goods Case and Pallet Standard (CoP060) ("Case and Pallet Standard").

The operation will be established and audited against legal standards as well as the Global Standard, in particular with reference to segregation, hygiene and traceability rules.

The Contractor shall work withABCto adhere to the required Supply Chain Security requirements required byABCand notified to the Contractor for all the markets in whichABCoperates, both local and international, including C-TPAT.

The Contractor shall (and shall procure that all sub-contractors shall) co-operate fully and promptly with the transport provider and all other third party service providers ofABCin relation to all activities relating to this Agreement and any points of interoperability or dependency between the Services and the services to be provided by the transport provider and/or such third party service providers.

The parties acknowledge thatas at the date of the Agreementthe Contractor's model is based on certain assumptions in relation to the operational profile of the Services as set out inAppendix 2 to Schedule2 (Charges)andthe Contractorwill report toABCby reference tosuchassumptions.

TYPES OF PRODUCT

Product will arrive on pallets and in case multiples or in containers in loose form. Pallets will be a variety of heights.The Contractor will be required to deal with a variety of pallets including standard Chep blue pallets, euro pallets, dollies and white export pallets All pallets fromABCfactories will be labelled, some pallets from Bought-In- Finished- Goods (BIFG) providers will be labelled and some will need to be labelled by Contractor upon receipt. The Contractor shall label cases and pallets in accordance with the Case and Pallet Standard, the example labels set out in Appendix 2 to this Schedule and any other requirements ofABCnotified to Contractor from time to time.

Pallet heights and weights will range in accordance withABCrequirements. As at the date of the Agreement the pallet heights range from 1.1M to 1.8M (TBC) and weights range from 250kg to1200 kg. Individual case weight ranges from 0.5kg to 7kg. These requirements may vary in accordance withABC' requirements as notified byABCto Contractor from time to time. Height and weight profiles as perABCprovided information:

All Products are ambient food grade products in a variety of formats including cans, bags, pouches, boxes and point of sales displays (POS).

CONTRACTOR'S SYSTEM

ABCuses SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system. The Contractor shall provide a Warehouse Management System (WMS) that can interface with the Customer Systems and provide:

Stock management of Products in the Warehouse or otherwise in the possession of the Contractor

Total product traceability

Drive all operational activities in the Warehouse

Interface withABCchosen transport provider (as notified byABCto Contractor from time to time).

Messages will be received by the Contractor from Customer's System for inbound deliveries of Products to Warehouse. The Contractor shall manage stocks of Product in the Contractor's System from the point of receipt by the Contractor. Outbound orders will be received byABCfromABCs customers and passed from Customer's System to the Contractor's System for action by the Contractor. The Contractor's System will need to ensure messaging back to Customer's System at every stage of the process.

The Contractor shall comply with the requirements set out in Schedule 9 (IT and IT Specification/ Interface Specification).

VOLUME FORECASTING

As part of the annual budgeting process set out in Schedule 2 (The Charges)ABCwill provide the Contractor with an annualised view ofABC' storage and throughput requirements, which will be reviewed and updated periodically in line with business change. Initial modelled volumes are as per the material flow below.

ORDER MANAGEMENT - INBOUND FROM FACTORY AND BIFG

ABCwill provide the Contractor with an estimate of the number of pallets / loads from factories to be delivered to Warehouse. Lead time will vary from Day1 for Day1 to Day1 for Day3.

Bought In Finished Goods suppliers will be expected to book in deliveries by telephone or email to the Contractor with the Warehouse at least 48 hours prior to delivery, although there will be occasions when due to just in time manufactureABCmay require this time to be reduced and the Contractor will be required to accommodate such reduced timescales.

GOODS IN AND CHECKING

The Contractor shall be required to manage the inbound vehicle schedule for all inbound deliveries.

Depending on the delivery type (single and double deck, double deck fixed and moving floor, box and curtain side, handball containers and containers with slipsheets), Product will arrive through a bay door or dock and the ability to unload from the side or through the rear shall be required.

The Contractor shall be responsible for the unloading and receipt of Product.

This function includes the unloading of single deck, double deck, curtain-siders, handball containers and containers with slip sheets using a variety of equipment to an inbound marshalling area.RFQ estimated splits: curtain siders- Ashford grocery, container= 0% of grocery, slipsheets=0% of grocery.

The Contractor will be required to check and break seals on inbound delivery and Contractor is responsible for recording and maintaining records of inbound seal numbers.

Loose Product arriving in containers will be unloaded and palletised by Contractor to agreed ti-his, prior to being wrapped and labelled for putaway into the racking or block stack area.

0% of pallets and loose Product are checked against the manifest and the ASN supplied by the transport provider to ensure the correct SKU, product and number of cases are on each pallet. Any discrepancies against the manifest and/or Advanced Shipping Notification (ASN) includingany damages will be recorded (and photographed if appropriate) and promptly advised toABCby email.

Quality checks shall be made by Contractor as part of the unloading process (to ensure that Product is not damaged and corresponds to the ASN and manifest paperwork referred to above. Such checks shall include any checks required in the Global Standard and the following minimum checks: ASN correctly booked in, product booked in corresponds with the ASN paperwork, checking pallet ID, item code, BBE, batch, quantity, EAN, missing pallet, over-allocated pallets, taints, foreign bodies, pest and contamination that can be identified visually at pallet level. An exceptions report shall be prepared by Contractors on the inbound quality check form approved byABCand shall be issued toABCvia email immediately (and at the latest within 24 hours of the load arrival). If there is a problem with any Product, this Product will be segregated by Contractor into a separate area until a decision is reached as to what action to take.

Product shall be confirmed by the Contractor as receipted into the Warehouse using RF scanners, and BIFG pallets shall be labelled by the Contractor in readiness for putaway.

Details provided in the ASN will be confirmed thus establishing a record of batch and expiry date where relevant. 1 single SKU / batch combination per pallet received.

PUTAWAY

Once pallets have been checked and confirmed onto the system, the pallets are putaway in either the very narrow aisle racking (VNA) or the adjustable pallet racking (APR) section. This is controlled by the Contractor's System using segregation, zoning and any segregation/constraint rules as set out in the Global Standard and in order to optimise efficiency of the Services including to meet the Productivity Rates.

Under standard operations, all Product shall be put away into reserve locations. However, should there be a requirement to cross-dock Product through the Warehouse as a result of any late production necessitating product to be immediately despatched from the Warehouse the Contractor shall fulfil such requirement. This is estimated as <0% of Sweet Treats volume.

The Contractor's System shall determine the optimum location for the pallet to be stored, taking into account the restrictions of pallet height and weight. The putaway shall be confirmed using RF scanners, by firstly scanning the pallet ID followed by the racking location bar code.

STORAGE

The Contractor shall:

Ensure stock location integrity within the Warehouse.

Recover and make good"pallet falls", whilst in their custody.- Ensure that housekeeping is maintained in line with the processes set out in the Global Standard and BRC Standard.

All internal movements of pallets for housekeeping or storage efficiency purpose are to be recorded on the Contractor's System.

REPLENISHMENT

Replenishment of pallets should only occur for case picked volume. Pallets shall be moved from either the VNA racking or APR racking reserve locations to replenish the case pick locations within the APR racking or gravity tunnel racking. The replenishment activity includes having to add any residual cases onto the pallet, removing any shrinkwrap or other packaging material, and removing the old pallet from the pickface.

ORDER MANAGEMENT - OUTBOUND FROM WAREHOUSE

Orders shall pass from Customer's System to the Contractor's System and be visible in the'order well in a regular and timely manner. Receipt of the transport despatch schedule from the transport provider will provide order grouping and despatch time enabling the Contractor to release the order to be picked. The Contractor must ensure the order is picked and delivery paper work produced by the Contractor in the form specified byABC(and onABC' stationery) in time to meet the scheduled collection time for the load as set out on the transport dispatch schedule.

ABCwill provide as much visibility as it is able to, to ensure orders are completed, however, if stock of Product is due to be received to meet an order the Contractor will be required to wait until the latest possible time that day that the Contractor can start pickingto ensure maximum order fillbefore the planned despatch time before commencing picking of orders to maximise the availability of stock.

PICK

The pick will be either full pallet pick or case pick and the principle of'first in, first out will be adopted unlessABC' customer agreed specific requirements require otherwise.ABCwill send to the Contractor, within the sales order, the minimum age requirement (i.e.the minimum best before end date on the Product to be sent to theABC' customer as defined on the order) that theABC' customer will accept and any specific requirements or instructions relating to that customer. The Contractor shall fulfil the order with the oldest Product stock in the warehouse that meets the customer requirement.

Full pallet pick will be carried out within the VNA racking or the standard APR racking reserve locations. The pick itself will be confirmed to the WMS using RF scanners.

Case picking will be done at ground level within the standard APR racking area or gravity pick tunnels using appropriate equipment. The pick itself will be confirmed to the Contractor's System using RF scanners or voice confirmation. The Contractor will be required to comply with any special instructions of aABCcustomer to provide Product on a single Product per pallet basis.

An efficient walk sequence which reduces any potential Product damage by engaging a heavy-to-light profile shall be created and used by the Contractor. This will be regularly reviewed by the Contractor throughout the contract term to ensure Good Industry Practice and optimum Product allocation in the case picking area.

All picks shall be controlled through the Contractor's System thus maintaining appropriate traceability of Product through all associated activities.

A number of dynamic pick locations based on RFQ levels will be created to handle any sudden demand changes and the requirement for different Best-Before-End's (BBEs) by customer to the SKUs picked at case level.

The Contractor shall generate and exceptions report which details any shortages (e.g.as a result of a Product on an order than cannot be loaded) and provide such report toABCas soon as practicable.Any shortages will be investigated by the Contractors' stock team to firstly understand the issue, and to try and resolve the problem.

MARSHALLING AND LOADING

All picked volume of Product shall be marshalled and checked within the outbound marshalling area. If any Product is to be sent overseas the Contractor shall, where required byABCbe responsible for sealing the relevant containers and recording such seals.

Product which has been picked at case level will be securely stretch wrapped and labelled in readiness for loading in accordance with the Global Standard and Good Industry Practice. Case picked pallets require a single handling label detailing quantity by sku as set out in the example in Appendix 2 to this Schedule.

Loading will be onto a mix of single deck, double deck, curtain-siders or 20ft and 40ft containers using appropriate equipment. Pallets will be confirmed as loaded onto the Contractor's System and need to be scanned individually on to the trailer.

There are a mix of live loading and stand trailers. Depending on the trailer type, Product shall be loaded through a bay door or a dock.

For export customers there are certain specific requirements:

When required byABCon 48 hours' notice, the Contractor shall make the marshalled load available for stock inspection by aABCnominated vet, on site at the Warehouse prior to loading

The Contractor will make available the facility for 20ft or 40ft containers to be hand balled rather than pallet loaded. An agreement will be reached between the parties in writing to the management of this process in terms of required lead times, frequency and costs

The Contractor must adhere to customer/market specific loading requirements, where specified byABCwithin the order notification

A shunt vehicle and driver shall be available to move any trailers on/off docks and bays as required. Note that it is the hauliers responsibility to ensure that vehicle loads are strapped adequately safe and reach their destination in the expected quality. The Contractor is responsible for loading Product and providing access to straps. The Contractor shall load Product in accordance with the Global Standard and HSE Guidance and shall ensure that the process of loading does not compromise the security of the Product or the vehicle or the weight of distribution of the loads. If the transport vehicle is to carry multiple deliveries of Product the Contractor shall ensure the Products are loaded so that they can be unloaded efficiently in accordance with the transport dispatch schedule.

INDIRECT ACTIVITIES

The Contractor shall also be responsible for a number of other indirect activities to support the main activities listed above. These functions include staff briefings, warehouse cleaning and hygiene, and returns management, pallet sortation (which the Contractor shall carry out in accordance with the Case and Pallet Standard), product sampling, samples order picking and packing and training. The Contractor shall carry out such activities in accordance with the Global Standards and anyABCinstructions notified byABCto the Contractor from time to time.

STOCK MANAGEMENT

Product shall normally be selected for pick based on remaining shelf life, and against customer specific requirements. However, whereABCinstructs otherwise, stock may also have to be selected based on other criteria such as return of specific batches or particularly short-dated stock.

Stock of Product will be counted on a perpetual cycle, all locations to be counted four times in a twelve month period. There shall be a regime of more specific checks including empty slot checks, location accuracy checks, regular and frequent pick face checks and checks of dynamic locations.

The Contractor shall establish the root cause of any Product stock inaccuracies whether related to IT systems, processes or human error.

Stock management shall be reported toABCas follows:

Reporting of stock differences between Customer's System and Contractor's System daily

Gross / net stock adjustments by reason per Accounting Period

Damage in warehouse by reason with trends per Accounting Period

Location accuracy per Accounting Period

Empty slot accuracy per Accounting Period

Returns volume / reason per Accounting Period

Any stock issues that may have a financial or service implication shall be brought by the Contractor to the attention ofABCimmediately.

PEAK MANAGEMENT

During peak periods, it is envisaged that the stock holding capacity of the Principal Warehouse could be exceeded. The Contractor will be responsible for managing any overflow requirement in a mutually agreed location to the same standards as are required and as are in place at the Principal Warehouse (unless otherwise agreed withABC). This shall include the transfer of relevant stock and appropriate stock management, hygiene, operations management and control.

Overall stock visibility will continue to be maintained, through ad hoc reports or agreed interfaces between Contractor's Systems and host systems for outside storage. However, individual stock locations in outside storage may not be visible toABCvia theABCSystems, other than by physically interrogating local systems and records and in this event the Contractor shall providerABCwith a schedule of stock to enableABCto reconcile the stock held in such outside storage withABCSystems.

RETURNS

The objective of any returns process is to ensure good Product stock is received and processed as quickly as possible and returned to stockholding to limit any mis-rotation and subsequent loss toABC. Annual returns volumes estimated at 120,000 cases (RFQ volume).

If despatched Product is to be returned to the Warehouse, resulting from a collection order place byABC, thenABCshall advise the Contractor in advance in writing andABCshall instruct the appropriate haulier accordingly.

Upon receipt, instructions are to be taken fromABCregarding the intended disposition of such stock based on known quality criteria and in accordance with the Global Standard.

Appropriate action shall then be taken by the Contractor based onABC' instructions.

For any Product returns resulting from customer refusals, rejections or POD corrections, then the haulier shall liaise directly with the Contractor to ensure timely notification of return of that stock. The Contractor shall adviseABCof such customer refusal, rejection or POD correction andABCwho shall give instruction to the Contractor in relation to the treatment of such stock.

HEALTH & SAFETY

The Contractor shall at all times carry out its operations in such a way as to comply with its obligations and duties under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 as a minimum and as detailed in their health and safety statements.

The Contractor shall maintain a record of every incident relevant to safety, occurring whether or not the same results in personal injury or damage to property and shall provideABC, on request, with access to such records for inspection purposes. The Contractor shall submit a written report of any accident or dangerous occurrence as is required by law to provide to the relevant authority and shall promptly provide a copy of such report toABCwhere reasonably required.

The Contractor shall carry out safety audits on a regular basis against all operational and documented procedures. These audits must be carried out by approved and qualified personnel.

The Contractor shall comply with the H&S Standard and the HSE Guidance.

Risk Assessments

Risk Assessments shall be completed by a competent person(s) on all the Contractor tasks that are considered to be a potential hazard. A safe system of working (SSW") shall be completed for each task that has been risk assessed. Once completed the SSW shall be communicated to all relevant personnel and be signed off and dated by the developer of the SSW and all personnel who will be undertaking the tasks.

Manual Handling Guidelines

The Contractor shall ensure that all manual handling that will be carried out on site should be risk assessed by a competent person(s). A risk management plan shall be compiled by the Contractor based on the findings where the highest risks are prioritised for action with the emphasis on whoever controls the relevant operation owning the risk assessment.

The Contractor shall ensure that all risk assessments should be kept on file and should be made available toABC, on request, for audit purposes.

Training

The Contractor shall ensure that all its employees, workers and sub-contractors are fully trained and competent to complete the task(s) they are required to do and provide the Services. The Contractor shall ensure that all training must be completed by a competent person(s). Full training records will be kept up to date and be signed and dated by the trainee and the trainer or a responsible manager.

It is the responsibility of the Contractor to ensure that training and development contributes to the effectiveness of its operations, and to provide opportunities for the individual employee to develop his/her talents within the manpower needs of the business. This will be achieved by the Contractor:

Ensuring that all employees are fully aware of the structure and activities of the Contractor and of their relationship withABC

Providing training to a level which ensures efficient performance of the job for which each employee is recruited and thereafter to help him/her to realise his/her full potential, as far as is consistent with the needs of the business.

Promoting and teaching methods of working which ensure that satisfactory standards of health, safety and welfare are maintained.

Induction Policy

The Contractor shall ensure that a site safety policy will be in place for visitors and sub-contractors, a copy of which will be provided by the Contractor toABCupon request.

Management Qualifications Requirements

The Contractor shall have a manager responsible for health and safety who holds a relevant, recognised qualification. They must be aware of safety legislation, risk awareness, risk management, risk assessment, accident investigation & safe working procedures. This manager should be suitably qualified and trained.

Near Miss Recording

The Contractor shall ensure that all near misses must be recorded on a near miss/incident form. Once completed, the form must be handed in to a manager in the area where the incident took place.

Trend Analysis

TheContractorshall collate all data relating to environmental, health & safety incidents and shall make such data available to be reviewed byABC.

Fire safety

The Contractor shall ensure that the Warehouse has zoned roof sprinklers and where racking is over 10 metres, the Warehouse shall have in-rack sprinklers every second level in the standard racking and every level in the flow rackingor as otherwise required byABC' insurer (as notified byABCto the Contractor in writing).

ENVIRONMENT & QUALITY

The Contractor shall comply fully with the requirements of all the appropriate site environmental and quality policies.

FOOD & HYGIENE STANDARDS

ABCoperates full traceability of inventory from manufacturing to delivery point location. The Contractor shall comply withABCquality standards for traceability and quality controls in accordance with the Global Standard.

FOOD LEGISLATION COMPLIANCE

The Contractor shall ensure that its facilities, vehicles and management of its operational practices shall comply with the requirements of Applicable Law relating to food safety.

REPORTING

The Contractor shall provide a range of management information and reports on a daily, weekly, periodical and annual basis. These shall include information on health & safety, operational performance, service performance, stock, finance and continuous improvement and the following specific information:

Health & Safety RIDDORS, lost time incidents per 100,000 labour hours, other accidents and incidents

Operational pick accuracy, on-time despatch, on-time delivery, OTIF performance, damages, progress against audit results, MHE performance

Inventory Perpetual Inventory (PI) status adjustments and accuracy, returns tracking, customer claims

Financial split by business unit, adherence to operating budget and flex budget and management of variances, productivity tracking, CI performance, utility costs

HR review of headcount, absence, staff turnover, disciplinary issues

The Contractor will be required to meet or exceed the Service Levels and performance against these levels will be monitored and communicated.

RECORDS

The Contractor shall keep records of all reports required under this Schedule for a minimum of 7 years from the date of their creation.

SECURITY

Site security arrangements will be deployed as per guidelines set out in the Global Standard, and as agreed with theABCproject implementation team. This includes adequate control of visitors to the site.

Security of vehicle loads outside of the perimeter of the Warehouse, either inbound or outbound, is not within the scope of this operational specification.

DAMAGES

All damages whether identified at the point of unloading (Goods In), or damages incurred whilst in the custody and control of the Contractors shall be recorded (where possible including photographs) and reported toABC. Such damages will be segregated into a separate area until a decision is reached as to what action to take.

OPERATING HOURS

The Warehouse shall operate twenty four hours per day, seven days per week if required but excluding:

Christmas Day; and

New Years Day

Bank holidays (excluding Christmas Day and New Years Day) are assumed to be normal working days.

For Christmas Day and New Years Day arrangements will be discussed and agreed withABCand will be based upon customer requirements but the Contractor will be expected to provide a minimum level of cover as follows:

Christmas Eve / New Years Eve open until 22:00

Boxing Day / New Years Day re-open 14:00

Part 2 - The Charges

With effect from Full Service Commencement DateABCshall pay the following Charges for the provision of the Services:

2.1.1the Management Fee; and

2.1.2all such costs charges and expenses of the nature set out in the Annual Budget and as are (a) wholly, reasonably exclusively and properly incurred by the Contractor or on its behalf in relation to its performance of the Services, having used reasonable endeavours to mitigate such costs and (b) fully accounted for in its books and records relating to the Services and (c) not disputed byABC(acting reasonably) in accordance with paragraph 2.8 of this Schedule 2 and reduced in accordance with the procedures set out in this Schedule 2 (the"Costs").

in each case to be calculated and paid in accordance with this Schedule 2.

The Contractor will maintain separate records relating to the Charges. IfABCreasonably believes that there has been anovercharge or other error by the Contractor in the Charges then it shall notify the Contractor of this fact in writing. If the Contractor has not investigated the matter and reported toABCin writing within 21 days of receipt of such notification, or ifABCis not reasonably satisfied with the Contractors explanation contained in such report, then the Contractor will, in addition to the rights and obligations set out at Clause23(Access to Premises, Auditing and Product Data) of the Agreement, allowABCand any of its Group Companies and their respective authorised servants or agents access (at all reasonable times and upon reasonable notice) to all of theContractors Personnel and to the Records and all books, records, correspondence, receipts, invoices and other papers of every kind in the possession of the Contractor pertaining to this Agreement reasonably required byABCto investigate and verify the Charges in relation to this Agreement.

If either the Contractors report or the investigation and verification carried out in accordance with paragraph 2.2of this Schedule 2 reveal an overcharge toABCthen the Contractor shall comply with the provisions of Clause23.3as if such overcharge was discovered pursuant to that Clause.

The Contractor shall retain the documents and records referred to in paragraph 2.2of this Schedule 2 for a period of seven years from expiry of this Agreement and, until such date, allowABCand any of its Group Companies at all reasonable times and on reasonable notice access thereto and to the Contractors Personnel and its facilities as set out in paragraph 2.2of this Schedule 2.

All Charges are exclusive of VAT (if any) and any other taxes or statutory charges imposed from time to time by any government or other regulatory authority.ABCshall pay to the Contractor such VAT (if any) as may properly be chargeable by the Contractor under legislation from time to time in force, upon the provision of the Services or any other sums payable byABCto the Contractor under the terms of this Agreement, subject to provision toABCby the Contractor of a valid VAT Invoicefor the same.

If there is any question, difference or dispute which may arise concerning any part of the Costs referable to any Accounting Period thenABCmay withhold payment of such excess amount (or any part thereof) which is subject to the dispute (the"Disputed Amount").

ABCshall within 7 days of receiving the Invoice from the Contractor give written notice to the Contractor of its reasons for disputing the Disputed Amount.ABCand the Contractor shall then use all reasonable endeavours to resolve the dispute (such endeavours to include discussion at the next following monthly meeting referred to in Schedule 4 meeting but if they have not done so within 30 days from Contractor's receipt of the notification of the dispute, then such dispute shall be resolved in accordance with Clause 37. If it is agreed or determined that the Disputed Amount or any part of it should be paid to the Contractor such amountshall be paid or satisfied in accordance with paragraph 3.6 of this Schedule 2.

Part 3 Charges and Payment

The Charges for each Accounting Period shall be accounted for in that Accounting Period and reconciled in the immediately following Accounting Period.

The Contractor shall ensure that any rebates or other payments obtained from its suppliers or sub-contractors for the provision of goods and services in any Accounting Period, in providing the Services, shall be deducted from the Costs for that Accounting Period.

On the first Business Day of each Accounting Period, the Contractor shall provide toABCa valid VAT invoice setting out the relevant latest budgeted or re-forecasted amount in respect of the Costs (as set out in the agreed Annual Budget or re-forecast) and the Management Fee which is attributable to that Accounting Period (the"Invoice").

On or before the fifteenth Business Day of each Accounting Period the Contractor shall provide toABCManagement Accountswhich shall include a statement reconciling Charges actually incurred in the Accounting Period prior to the current Accounting Period against the amount already invoiced pursuant to Paragraph 3.3above together with a valid VAT invoice or credit note (showing the Contractors VAT number and complying with all UK laws and regulations) adjusting for the amount already invoiced for that Accounting Period pursuant to Paragraph 3.3.

The correct purchase order number must be quoted on all invoices andABCshall accept no liability whatsoeverfor invoices which do not bear such purchase order number.Invoices shall not be deemed received byABCunless submitted electronically to portal nominated byABCor such other address asABCnotifies theContractorfrom time to time.

All invoices shall be paid in accordance with Clause14of the Agreement.

Any dispute in relation to any Costs referred to in this Part 3 of Schedule 2 shall be resolved in accordance with Paragraph2.7of this Schedule 2.

At each weekly meeting referred to in Schedule 4(Contract Management, Information and Reporting)the Contractor andABCshall review the following:

the most recently provided Invoice(s), statement and Adjustment provided pursuant to paragraphs 3.3 and 3.4 of this Part 3 of Schedule 2;

Service Levels performance;

Change Requests which relate to the current Annual Budget;

Management Accounts.

Part 4 The Budget Process

The First Year Budget shall apply for the first Budget Year.

ABCshall by no later than 31 December in any Budget Year provide to the Contractor a forecast of Product distribution and Services requirements for the following Budget Year.

The Contractor shall by no later than 31 January in any Budget Year provide toABCa draft Annual Budget for the following Budget Year (the"Proposed Annual Budget"). Such Proposed Annual Budget shall:

4.2.1be adjusted to reflect any provisions made in the 4thtab of the spreadsheet at Appendix 1 (R&M and Delaps Costs) ;

4,2,2only otherwise increase the Costs from the Annual Budget for the current Budget Year:

4.2.2.1to the extent that such increase(s) can be reasonably justified (on theproduction of reasonable evidence) by an increase in the Contractor's costsor;

4.2.2.2a change in Applicable Law to the extent such change in Applicable Law:

(a)specifically and directly relatesto warehousing of ambient foodproducts in the UK; or

(b)requires an increase in Contractor Personnel salaries.

and had not been, and could not reasonably be, contemplatedby the Contractor on or before the date of this Agreement

4.2.3include any specific requirements notified to the Contractor byABCin writing and shall include estimates of all major items of expenditure for the following Budget Year broken down on an Accounting Period basis, accompanied by all necessary commentary and in particular but without limitation the following:

  1. Management Fee
  2. Continuous improvement plan
  3. Business plan current year plus 3 following years
  4. Service Levels
  5. Contractors authority procedures

The parties shall negotiate the proposed Annual Budget in good faith and agree such budget as soon as practicable.

In the event that the proposed Annual Budget is not agreed in accordance with paragraph 4.2 of this Schedule 2 prior to the commencement of the relevant Budget Year (after the same proposed Annual Budget have been escalated in accordance with Clause 37 (if required in accordance with its terms)) then the lower of:

the Proposed Annual Budget; and

the actual Costs incurred in respect of the Budget Year immediately preceding the relevant Budget Year plus the percentage by which the Consumer Price Index (CPI) last published prior to the commencement of the relevant Budget Year exceeds CPI for the same month in the preceding Budget Year,

shall be deemed to comprise the Annual Budget for the relevant Budget Year.

The parties acknowledge the importance of good budget discipline therefore theContractorshall use all reasonable endeavours to ensure that in each Budget Year the aggregate amount of Costs incurred for that Budget Year does not exceed the Annual Budget (as varied pursuant to Part 6 (Change))of this Schedule.

If theContractoranticipates that there is a reasonable prospect that the amount incurred for one or more types of Cost shall materially exceed the amount allotted to that Cost in the Annual Budget for that Budget Year then:

It shall promptly notifyABC

explaining why the budget for that Cost might be exceeded

demonstrating that the risk that the budget for the Cost might be exceeded has not arisen due to theContractor's breach of this Agreement (including its obligation to apply Good Industry Practice)

demonstrating that theContractorhas used all reasonable endeavours to avoid exceeding the budget for such Cost

the steps theContractorproposes to take to mitigate the budget overrun for that Cost, or defer such overrun so that it is dealt with in accordance with Part 4 (Budget Process), or adjustments to the budgets for other Costs so that the aggregate Annual Budget is still met

whether the issue is entitled to be addressed pursuant to Part 6 (Change)

any proposed change to the relevant Annual Budget

("Budget Plan")

Provided the Supplier has fulfilledits obligations at paragraph 4.5and 4.6theContractormayincur the Costsbeyond the amount set out in the Annual Budgetit considers, acting reasonably,necessaryat that momentto provide the Servicesin accordance with this Agreement.

The parties shall at the next weekly meeting heldpursuant to Schedule 4 (Contract Management, Information and Reporting) discuss the Budget Plan using reasonable endeavours to agree the Budget Plan and the Annual Budget shall be varied in accordance with that agreed Budget Plan.

If the Costs in the Budget Plan are an overspend compared to the Annual Budget, because they have not been wholly, reasonably, exclusively and properly incurred by theContractorin relation to its performance of the Services in accordance with this Agreement or because theContractorshould have been able to use its reasonable endeavours to mitigate them, theContractorshall not be entitled to charge the Management Fee in respect of such Costs.

Part 5 Contractors Personnel Remunerations

The Contractor agrees that the remunerations for the Transferring Employees shall not be changed without the prior written consent ofABC.

The Contractor agrees that the remunerations for any newly recruited Contractors Personnel shall be no more than that of the departing employee unless agreed in writing byABCprior to the new employee being offered the position.

In the event that the Contractor wishes to alter any of the Contractors Personnels terms and conditions of employment, the Contractor discuss the proposed changes withABCand shall not proceed with any proposed changes without the prior written approval ofABCor, if such proposed changes are an increase in salary, in accordance with the process set out in paragraph 4.2.2.2 (b).

The Contractor agrees thatABCshall not be liable for the costs of any of the Contractors Personnel employed by the Contractor on any work other than that in the provision of the Services and not for the benefit ofABC. For the avoidance of doubt the costs for any Contractors Personnel employed by the Contractor on any work other than in the provision of the Services shall be reimbursed toABCat a rate equivalent to an hourly proportion of the Contractors Personnels salary.

ABCagrees that it shall be liable for the costs of any of the Contractors Personnel deployed from other services to work on the provision of the Services where the deployment has been agreed in advance and in writing byABC. For the avoidance of doubt the costs for any Contractors Personnel deployed by the Contractor in the provision of the Services shall be charged by the contractor toABCat a rate equivalent to an hourly proportion of the Contractors Personnels salary.

Part 6 Change

The parties acknowledge that the objective is to provide the Services at the lowest cost required to provide those Services and otherwise fulfil the Agreement.

The parties also acknowledge that during the term of this Agreement the requirements of the Services will vary and that will have an impact on the utilisation or productivity of the Principal Warehouse for example lower stock levels may mean that theABCdoes not require the full capacity of the Warehouse or a change in delivery frequency or mix may mean that less activity or picking is required in the Principal Warehouse.

The Dataset sets out the basis on which the Warehouse Services has been calculated as at the date of this Agreement.

ABCshall provide the Contractor with an appropriate updated Dataset based on 2017 data on or prior to31 December 2017so that the Contractor canreview that updated Dataset, comparing it against the Dataset attached to this Agreement and identify if the differences between the Datasets demonstrate a material difference inutilisation and productivitywhich the Contractor acting reasonably considers means the First Budget should be adjusteddue to the Costs arising in relation to such differences.If the Contractor orABCconsiders that theFirstBudget should be varied to reflect theanticipatedutilisation and/or productivity of the Principal Warehousebased on the updated Datasetthen they shall notify the other partyin writingproviding reasonable evidence to identify the change in utilisation/productivity from that set out in the Dataset and proposed change to theFirstBudget.The parties acknowledge that the First Budget should only be varied due to differences between the updated Dataset and the Datasetattached to this Agreement, and if there is no material difference between the updated Dataset and the Dataset attached to this Agreement then the First Budget shall not be changed (unless the parties agree otherwise in writing).

The Contractor shall track utilisation and productivity of the Principal Warehouse and identify when its utilisation and/or productivity is varying from the Dataset (and has not arisen due to the breach of the Contractor of this Agreement) and identifying how as a result the relevant Annual Budget should be varied. If the Contractor orABCconsiders that the Annual Budget should be varied to reflect the utilisation and/or productivity of the Principal Warehouse then they shall notify the other party providing reasonable evidence to identify the change in utilisation/productivity from that set out in the Dataset and proposed change to the relevant Annual Budget, upon receipt the parties shall use reasonable endeavours to agree the change within 10 Business Days of that notification, and failing agreement either party may refer the dispute to the Dispute Resolution Procedure.

Where utilisation of the Principal Warehouse is such that the capacity of the Principal Warehouse is not, or can reasonably be anticipated will not, be fully deployed then the Contractor shall proactively seek to identify means by which the excess space can be deployed so as to generate an income, such as identifying an appropriate third party customer to use that space. The Contractor shall review their existing customer base, enquiries received from customers or potential customers, and otherwise identify potential users of that space and market the space to them (consulting withABCand regularly notifyingABCof progress). The Contractor shall give priority to any person identified as a potential customer for the space or equivalent space within 20 miles radius of the Principal Warehouse over any other solution. On identifying a potential third party customer for the excess space the Contractor shall consult withABCon the commercial terms with that customer. Unless the parties agree otherwise the third party customer shall be charged a share of the costs of operating the Principal Warehouse proportionate to their requirements. No person utilising the Principal Warehouse shall be entitled to better terms for that usage then those enjoyed byABCpursuant to this Agreement unlessABCexpressly agrees otherwise in writing.

The parties acknowledge that there is a relationship between the variable Costs and the utilisation of and activity in the Principal Warehouse. The parties therefore in principal agree that variable Costs should decrease in proportion to decreased utilisation/activity levels (and increase in proportion to increased utilisation/activity levels) subject to the productivity and mix set out in the Dataset not changing.The Contractor shall use reasonable endeavours to identify how the Costs can be reduced to reflect the utilisation of the Principal Warehouse including considering decreasing the cost of labour notifyingABCof subsequent proposed changes to the Costs

Part 7 Dilapidations

ABCis liable for theDilapidations payable under the Principal Warehouse Lease, net of the contributionsABCmakes towards the Dilapidations pursuant to a relevant Budget, save thatABCis not liable for any part of the Dilapidations which arises due to the Contractor's negligence or breach of this Agreement.

As the expiry or termination of the Principal Warehouse Lease approaches the parties shall collaborate and use all reasonable endeavours to reduce the liability for Dilapidations including negotiating with the Landlord.

Part 8 Capital Investment in the Principal Warehouse

The Contractor is investing 0,000,000(as at the date of this Agreement, subject to variation byagreement in writing between the parties) in the Capex Equipment (of which as at the date of the Agreement(which may be varied by agreement in writing between the parties) 000,000is in IT equipment) in the Principal Warehouse. That sum is depreciated to zero in a straight line over 10 years from the Full Service Commencement Date, except for IT equipment which is depreciated to zero in a straight line over 5 years.

Part 9 Other

If the Contractor moves from Principal Warehouse A to Principal Warehouse B then the Contractor is responsible for all costs arising from such move.
