Schedule 3

Service Levels

In this Schedule the following words andexpressions have the following meanings:

Accounting Periodhas the meaning given in Schedule 2 (Charges);
Bonus Sum(s)means the amount payable (if any) by ABC to the Contractor in accordance with this Schedule for exceeding the Target in respect of a Productivity Service Level or First Tier Service Level, as calculated in accordance with Table 1 of this Schedule;
Budget Yearhas the meaning given in Schedule 2 (Charges);
First Tier Service Levelmeans the Service Levels set out in Section 1 of this Schedule 3;
Malus Sum(s)means the amount payable (if any) by the Contractor to ABC in accordance with this Schedule for failure to meet the Target in respect of a Productivity Service Level or, the Minimum Performance Level, in respect of a First Tier Service Level, as calculated in accordance with Table 1 of this Schedule;
Minimum Performance Levelmeans in relation to each Service Level the minimum level of performance required (expressed as a %) in the column "Minimum Performance Level" in Table 2 of this Schedule 3 (as applicable);
Productivity Service Levelsmeans the productivity levels (identified by Code "PRODS") set out in Table 1 which are by reference to Tab 1 (Key Productivities) of the Dataset annexed at Appendix 2 of Schedule 2 (Charges);
Second Tier Service Levelmeans the Service Levels set out in Section 2 of this Schedule 3;
Targetmeans, in relation to a First Tier Service Level or Second Tier Service Level, the level of performance set out in the column "Target (%) per Accounting Period" in Table 1, Table 2 or Table 3 of this Schedule 3 (as applicable), and, in respect of a Productivity Service Level, the level of performance set out in the column "Target" of Table 1 of this Schedule 3;
Termination Thresholdmeans, in respect of Service Levels 1 to 5 (inclusive) failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in respect of a Service Level three (3) times or more in any rolling six (6) consecutive Accounting Periods and in respect of Service Level 4, any failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level.
  1. SERVICE LEVELS

This Schedule sets out the Service Levels in relation to the Services to be provided by the Contractor toABC. First Tier Service Levels are set out in Section 1 of this Schedule 3 and Second Tier Service Levels are set out in Section 2 of this Schedule 3.

  1. SERVICE LEVEL MANAGEMENT AND REPORTING PROCESS

All Service Levels detailed in this Schedule 3 shall be measured, reported and reviewed on a continuous basis and in accordance with this Schedule and Schedule 6 (Contract Management, Information and Reporting). A consolidated performance measure for each Service Level shall be calculated and reported toABCby Contractor for each week,eachAccounting Period and each Budget Year.

If any of the Service Levels fall below the Minimum Performance Level (in addition to the requirements set out in Clause 6 of the Agreement) or in relation to the Productivity Service Levels and the Second Tier Service Levels, the Target, meetings shall be convened between representatives of the parties to identify the root cause, identify an action plan and agree timescales to remedy as follows:

1 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling period: each parties' Account Director;

2 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling period: each parties' Regional Director;

3 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling period: each parties'Head of Procurement and a senior executive.

SERVICE FAILURE

Failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level for any First Tier Service Level and the Target for any Productivity Service Level in any Accounting Period will be dealt with inaccordance with Clause6.3of this Agreement and paragraphs 3.2to3.8(inclusive) below.

If the Termination Threshold is reached in respect of a First Tier Service Level this shall constitute a"Material Service Level Breach"andABCshall be entitled to terminate the Agreement.

Failure to meet the Target for any Second Tier Service Level in any Accounting Period will be dealt with in accordance with Section 2 of this Schedule 3.

In eachBudget Year, the Contractor's average performance will be measured against Table 1 below, and the appropriate Bonus Sum(s) or Malus Sum(s) will be calculated and paid in accordance withparagraph 3.6below.

In the event that in a Budget Year, the Contractor's average performance exceeds the Target for the relevant Productivity Service Level and/or the Minimum Performance Level in respect of the relevant First Tier Service Level, then the Contractor shall be entitled to the relevant Bonus Sum(s) attributable to such Service Level and level of performance as set out in the"Bonus Per Annum"columns of the table below.

TheContractorshall calculate and report toABCthe Malus Sum(s) and Bonus Sum(s) on an Accounting Period and Budget Year basis and:

such calculations and report shall be discussed by the partiesat the nextweekly Servicemeeting in accordance with Schedule 4 (Contract Management,Information and Reporting);

the Contractor shall pay the Malus Sum(s)as a deduction to the Charges within 30 days ofthe end of each Budget Year. If no further Charges fall due after the Malus Sum(s)accrue, the Contractor shall issue a credit note toABCfor a sum equal to any such Malus Sum(s)then outstanding, which shall be repayable by the Contractor toABCas a debt;

the Contractor shall invoice any Bonus Sumswithin30 days of the end of each Budget Yearand such invoice shall be paid in accordance with Clause 14.3 of this Agreement (Charges and Payment).

ABCshall be entitled to set off any Bonus Sums due to the Contractor against any Malus SumsduetoABCby notice in writing to the Contractor.

The maximum Malus Sum(s) and Bonus Sum(s) payable in respect of a Service Level are as set out in the"Malus (Max)"and"Bonus (Max)"columns of Table 1 respectively.

SECTION 2 : SECOND TIER SERVICE LEVELS

The Contractor will use all reasonable endeavours to achieve the Target for the Second Tier Service Levels through ongoing continuous improvement activities and initiatives. Where the Contractor fails to meet the Target in any Accounting Period, meetings shall be convened between both parties to identify root causes, agree remedial actions and timescales as set out in paragraph 2 of this Schedule 3 above. Such performance shall be reviewed at the Review Meetings where action plans will be agreed to further improve performance to move towards a best in class operation.

SERVICE LEVEL #6 : Fast Track Booking In

  1. MEASURE

The percentage of notified fast track vehicles received and corresponding stock being available within 90 minutes of vehicle arriving on site.

PURPOSE

To ensure that product lines urgently required for outbound movements are processed as a priority.

TARGET

0% of fast track to be booked in within 90 minutes of arrival on site.

MEANS OF MEASUREMENT

This will be measured via the Contractors inbound reporting mechanism. It will also be measured byABC stock availability reports.

FREQUENCY OF MEASUREMENT

Performance will be reviewed on a continuous basis but aggregate measurement will be appraised on an Accounting Period and cumulative year to date basis. From the Commencement Date onwards, the Contractor will formally report performance against the Target within 21 days of the end of each Accounting Period.

NON CONFORMANCE

The Contractor shall procure that a detailed corrective action report is produced immediately after any failure by the Contractor to achieve the Target during an Accounting Period.

Such corrective action report, when agreed byABC, must immediately be actioned by the Contractor where corrective action is required as a result of its own failure to achieve the required standard.

SOURCE OF DATA

The data to be extracted from the Extranet in a report format byABC. This is dependant upon GB input compliance.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR MEASUREMENT

ABCshall measure and verify whether the Contractor has achieved the Target using the measurements and the frequency specified above.

The Contractor to document evidence of the reasons for any non-conformance as required byABCfrom time to time.

NOTES

Communication of fast track loads will be betweenABC DRP Logistics team and the appropriate operational interface Contractor customer service team member.

SERVICE LEVEL #7 : Returns

  1. MEASURE

The percentage of returns processed within the agreed timeframes.

PURPOSE

To monitor the effective management of returns processing.

TARGET

All returns to be processed within the following timescales:

Grocery0% of Returns received to be processed in less than 48 hours

Sweet Treats0% Returns received to be processed in less than 24 hours (particularly important for managing remaining product life)

MEANS OF MEASUREMENT

This will be measured via the Contractors returns reporting mechanism.

FREQUENCY OF MEASUREMENT

Performance will be reviewed on a continuous basis but aggregate measurement will be appraised on an Accounting Period and cumulative year to date basis. From the Commencement Date onwards, the Contractor will formally report performance against the Target within 21 days of the end of each Accounting Period.

NON CONFORMANCE

The Contractor shall procure that a detailed corrective action report is produced immediately after any failure by the Contractor to achieve the Target during an Accounting Period.

Such corrective action report, when agreed byABC, must immediately be actioned by the Contractor where corrective action is required as a result of its own failure to achieve the required standard.

SOURCE OF DATA

ABCto provide a regularly updated log of outstanding returns.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR MEASUREMENT

The Contractor shall measure andABCshall verify whether the Contractor has achieved the Target using the measurements and the frequency specified above.

The Contractor to document evidence of the reasons for any non-conformance as required byABCfrom time to time.

The Exit Plan should consist of a list of processes to manage the exit, including in relation to the matters referred to in paragraph 4 below. It should be updated during the life of the Agreement by agreement between the parties and include any changes to the Agreement made under the Change Control Procedures. The provisions should be applicable in whatever circumstances termination arises.

  1. EXIT PLAN COMMENCEMENT

The Exit Plan will become effective pursuant to Clause32(Consequences of Termination).

The parties will, from the Exit Plan becoming effective, jointly establish anexitgroup comprising staff of both parties(which in the case of the Contractor have been approved byABC(acting reasonably)to manage disengagement of the Services and the Agreement and to implement the provisions of the Exit Plan("Exit Group"). Each party is to make available sufficient resources to meet the requirements of the Exit Group. The Exit Group will manage all the activities needed for the transfer of the Services from the Contractor toABCor any New Provider so that the transition is as carried out as seamlessly as possible.

  1. THE CONTRACTORS CHARGES/SERVICE LEVELS

ABCwill continue to pay Charges for Services provided during the Exit Plan, and the Services shall be taken to include allnecessarywork carried out by the Contractor in implementing the Exit Planas set out in the Exit Plan and agreed withABCin writing. The Services should continue to meet the Service Levels and the provisions of Schedule 3 will continue to apply in full, saveas otherwise agreed in writing by the parties.

  1. THE CONTRACTORS RESPONSIBILITIES

Many of the Contractors responsibilities are set out in the Agreement in Clause32(Consequences of Termination) and Schedule 7 (Employment Provisions). The provisions include return of Confidential Information. A timetable for these events should be set out in the Exit Plan especially if things are required before termination.

The Contractors responsibilities include:

Training- theContractorwill provide training toABCor any New Provider to enable reasonably competent,suitablyexperienced staff to operate and deliver services similar to the Services;

Staff- theContractorwill continue to meet all its staff related obligations set out in the Agreement and comply particularly withSchedule 7 (Employment Provisions)in respect of transferring employees;

Documentation and Records- theContractorshall provideABCor any New Provider with alldata from the Warehouse Management System,records, service deliveryreports and service documentation. Delivery of all records and other documentation set out in32.2(c)and32.2(d)will be in accordance with the dates specified in the Exit Plan;

Management Procedures- theContractorshall work in accordance with the management process, controls andprojectstyle defined in the current version of the Exit Plan;

Delivery of Assets- to be delivered in accordance with Clause32(Consequences of Termination) and the dates in the Exit Plan;

Novation or Assignment- upon theExitPlan being invoked, theContractorshall consult withABCto ascertain which (if any) contracts, leases, licences and other agreementsABCwishes to have novated or assigned to it or a New Provider. TheContractorshall atABCs request, novate or assign toABCor a New Provider all equipment contracts, leases, licences and other agreements whichABCs request shall be assigned or novated;

Licence to use any hardware, software or Intellectual Property- theContractorshall grant licences toABCor a New Provider to use the WMS or any other of theContractors Systems, software or hardware and data in these systems required byABC;

Return ofABCs Property and Confidential Information- In accordance with Clause32(Consequences of Termination) and dates in Exit Plan;

Principal Warehouse the Contractor is to leave the Principal Warehouse in a clean and tidy state;

Observation of Services-Observation of Services on notice of at least 7 days the Contractor is to permitABCor at its request, any New Provider to have access to the Contractors staff at reasonable times to observe the operational delivery of the Services during the Exit Period, to enable the Contractor to fulfil its obligations to transfer knowledge of the Services toABCor any New Provider

Avoidance of Unnecessary Costs- theContractoris to take all reasonable steps to co-operate withABCany New Provider topreventany avoidable costs incurred byABCor any New Provider as a result of theContractors acts or omissions in respect of the Exit Plan.

Transition Co-operation theContractorshallco-operate withABCand/or any New Provider in order to achieve a smooth transition of the Services to that party.

Warehouse Management System-The Contractor will provide access and training in the use of the Warehouse Management System (WMS) and other infrastructure and software.

Employment Provisions

  1. DEFINITIONS
Contractor Employeeany person employed or engaged or formerly employed or engaged by the Contractor or any of its Subcontractors in the provision of the Services at any time during the Term, including but not limited to the Transferring Employees, whose contracts of employment (by virtue of the Transfer Regulations) have or would have effect after a service provision change (as defined in the Transfer Regulations) resulting from termination or expiry of this Agreement, as if originally made between the employee and ABC or a New Provider;
Customer Employeeany person employed or engaged or formerly employed or engaged by either ABC or any Previous Supplier in the provision of the Services, whose contracts of employment (by virtue of the Transfer Regulations) have effect after a service provision change (as defined in the Transfer Regulations) pursuant to this Agreement, as if originally made between the employee and the Contractor or the Contractor's Subcontractor and who do not object to the transfer of their employment to the Contractor or the Contractor's Subcontractor or liabilities in respect of whom so transfer;
Exit Transferring Employeeany Contractor Employee who is listed in the Final Exit List;
Exit Transfer Datethe relevant date or dates on which a relevant transfer for the purposes of the Transfer Regulations takes effect on the termination or partial termination of this Agreement;
Final Exit Listhas the meaning given in paragraph 5.2 of this Schedule;
Payall emoluments and outgoings relating to employment including but not limited to PAYE, National Insurance Contributions, remuneration and benefits, pension and other contributions;
Potential Exit Transferring Employeea Contractor Employee who is, at the relevant time, assigned to the Services for the purposes of the application of the Transfer Regulations;
Previous Suppliermeans, means any third party engaged by ABC immediately before the Transfer Date to supply services fundamentally the same as any or all of the Services (as provided for by TUPE) and including for the Town Operation, GB Distribution Limited, for the Town Operation W Group Limited and for the Town Operation ABC;
Subcontractorfor the Contractor: any direct or indirect subcontractor of the Contractor and for ABC: the New Provider or the Previous Supplier, in each case (as the case may be) providing services which are fundamentally the same as the Services (as provided for by the Transfer Regulations) and which are provided by the Contractor under this Agreement;
Transfer Datethe relevant date or dates on which a relevant transfer for the purposes of TUPE takes effect in connection with the commencement of this Agreement or subsequent Service Commencement Date;
Transferring Employeethose Customer Employees who, as at the Transfer Date, are assigned to services carried out by ABC or a Previous Contractor which are fundamentally the same as the Services (as provided for by the Transfer Regulations);
Transferring Employee Termination Liabilitiesmeans any costs and payments incurred by the Contractor in terminating the employment of any Contractor Employee in respect of statutory and contractual notice payments and statutory and contractual redundancy payments and any payments due in respect of accrued but untaken holiday to which Transferring Employees are entitled upon termination of their employment due to redundancy;
Unexpected Exit Transferring Employeeany Contractor Employee whose employment is or liabilities in respect of whom are alleged to transfer to ABC or a New Provider and who is not an Exit Transferring Employee by virtue of their not being on the Final Exit List;
Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee Termination Liabilitiesmeans any and all actions, claims, proceedings, costs (including legal costs), losses, damages, fines, penalties, compensations, awards, demands, orders, expenses, payments and liabilities whatsoever and howsoever arising which ABC or the New Provider may suffer, incur, pay or be put to arising out of or in connection with the employment (or purported employment) or termination of employment (or purported employment) of any Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee (including, but not limited to, unfair dismissal, wrongful dismissal, statutory or enhanced redundancy payments, payments in lieu of notice, obligations to pay salary, wages, commission, bonus, remuneration or benefits, health and safety or any other requirements having legal effect connected with such employees or any payments made in relation to the purported employment of such employees (including Pay));

INFORMATION AND CONSULTATION OBLIGATIONS

Each party will, and will procure that its Subcontractors (and in the case ofABC, any Previous Suppliers and NewProviders) will, (i) comply with its or their respective obligations to inform and consult with employees and/or their appropriate representatives under the Transfer Regulations, (ii) provide any measures information to the relevant transferor as required under the Transfer Regulations, and (iii) provide such co-operation as may reasonably be required by the other party to effect a smooth transfer of any Transferring Employees or Exit Transferring Employees.

Where a party fails to comply with its obligations under paragraph 2.1 (i) and (ii) above, it will indemnify the other party or any of the relevant Subcontractors for any Employment Liabilities which that party, or Subcontractor incurs in relation to that failure.

COMMENCEMENT

ABCwill and will procure that the Previous Supplier will comply with its or their duties under Regulation 11 of the Transfer Regulations to provide Employee Liability Information regarding the Transferring Employees.

ABCwill be responsible for, and will indemnify the Contractor and any of its Subcontractors, as the case may be, in respect of all Pay and any other Employment Liabilities in relation to:

the Transferring Employees arising in respect of the period up to and including the Transfer Date; and

the employment or termination of employment byABCor the Previous Supplier prior to the Transfer Date of any person who is a Customer Employee but whose contract of employment does not transfer to the Contractor;

except as provided for by paragraphs 2.2 (information and consultation obligations) and 3.3 (liability for pre-contract proposals).

Within 28 days of the relevant Transfer Date,ABCwill pay the Contractor or any of its Subcontractors, as the case may be, an amount equivalent to the holiday pay for any holiday entitlement which has been accrued by the Transferring Employees but not taken as at the Transfer Date.

The Contractor will indemnifyABCand any of its Subcontractors for any Employment Liabilities incurred byABCand/or any of its Subcontractors, as the case may be, in respect of any proposal by the Contractor or any of its Subcontractors prior to or following the Transfer Date to make a change which amounts or would amount to a repudiatory breach of contract of employment of any potential Transferring Employee or is or would be a substantial change in working conditions to the material detriment of that employee as provided for by the Transfer Regulations.

DURING THE TERM

During the term of this Agreement,ABCshall be responsible for any Transferring Employee Termination Liabilities incurred by the Contractor in making any of the Contractor Employees redundant provided that:

the redundancy has been agreed in writing in advance byABC;

the redundancy arises in connection with any initiative under schedule15 (Continuous Improvement)or is necessary in order to properly resourceABCs requirements for the Services; and

the Contractor must use reasonable endeavours to avoid such redundancy which shall include but not be limited to an obligation to seek alternative redeployment opportunities.

The Contractor will be responsible for, and will indemnifyABCand the New Provider in respect of all Pay and other Employment Liabilities in relation to the Contractor Employees in respect of the period following and including the Transfer Date up to and including the Exit Transfer Date except as provided for by paragraphs 2.2 (information and consultation liabilities), 4.1 (cover for redundancy costs), 5.6 (liability for Exit Transferring Employees) and 5.8 (liability for pre Termination proposals).

TERMINATION PROVISIONS

Within seven days of notice of termination or partial termination of this Agreement or, in any event, no later than six months prior to expiry, the Contractor shall provide toABC, and to such third parties asABCmay reasonably require, such information in accordance with relevant data protection legislation in relation to the Contractor Employees as may reasonably be requested byABCincluding but not limited to:

an anonymised list of all current Contractor Employees and for each such employee the job description, length of service, age, immigration status, remuneration and the proportion of their working time spent on the provision of the Services, indicating whether any such employee is a Potential Exit Transferring Employee;

an organisational chart setting out how the Contractor Employees fit in with the Contractor organisation as a whole, indicating teams, team leaders, reporting lines and management for the Contractor Employees;

details of any other terms and conditions of employment of the Contractor Employees; and

details of any other agreement or arrangement (including with any trade union representative body) which may affect the employment of any Potential Exit Transferring Employee.

No later than 28 days prior to a relevant Exit Transfer Date, the Contractor will provide toABCand to the New Provider the information set out in paragraph 5.1 above in relation to each Potential Exit Transferring Employee and such additional information as is required by Regulation 11 of the Transfer Regulations in relation to those employees, such information to include a list of the names of all Exit Transferring Employees (the"Final Exit List").

The Contractor will use its reasonable endeavours to ensure that all information disclosed under paragraphs 5.1 and 5.2 will be full, accurate and up-to-date, and will notifyABCand any New Provider in writing of any updates to such information immediately/ as soon as is reasonably practicable.

If there are any Unexpected Exit Transferring Employees at any time on or after the relevant Exit Transfer Date:

either party will, upon becoming aware of any Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee at any time on or after the relevant Exit Transfer Date, notify the other immediately or as soon as is reasonably practicable in writing of the identity of that Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee;

ABCor a New Provider, as the case may be, may terminate the employment of that Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee either in accordance with any procedure that may be given toABCor the New Provider in writing by the Contractor, or, where the Contractor does not specify any such procedure in writing within seven days of notification under paragraph 5.4(a) above, within 21 days of notification under paragraph 5.4(a) above;

provided the termination of the Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee takes place prior to the relevant Exit Transfer Date, or otherwise is effected byABCor a New Provider, in accordance with paragraph 5.4(b) above, the Contractor will indemnifyABCor the New Provider, as the case may be, against any Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee Termination Liabilities;

if the employment of an Unexpected Exit Transferring Employee is not terminated, or is not terminated in accordance with paragraph 5.4(b) above, that person will be deemed to have been an Exit Transferring Employee with effect from the relevant Exit Transfer Date.

The Contractor will not and will procure that its Subcontractors will not during the period of six months immediately preceding the termination of this Agreement (in whole or in part), or such other period of notice to terminate this Agreement in whole or in part where less than 6 months without the prior written consent ofABC(such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed):

other than for misconduct terminate or give notice to terminate the employment of any Potential Exit Transferring Employee;

other than in the ordinary course of business increase or reduce the number of Potential Exit Transferring Employees by more than0%;

propose, make or promise to make any material change to the remuneration or other terms and conditions of employment of any Potential Exit Transferring Employee that are not a contractual entitlement or which have not already been promised; or

replace any Potential Exit Transferring Employee.

ABCwill, or will procure that any New Provider or any of its or their Subcontractors will, be responsible for, and will indemnify the Contractor or any of its Subcontractors in respect of all Pay and any other Employment Liabilities in relation to the Exit Transferring Employees arising in respect of the period following and including the relevant Exit Transfer Date, except as provided for by paragraph 2.2 (liabilities for information and consultation).

Within 28 days of the relevant Exit Transfer Date, the Contractor will payABCor a New Provider an amount equivalent to holiday pay for any holiday entitlement which has been accrued by the Exit Transferring Employees but not taken as at the relevant Exit Transfer Date.

ABCwill indemnify the Contractor or any of its Subcontractors in respect of any Employment Liabilities it or they may suffer in respect of any proposal byABCor a New Provider or any of its or their Subcontractors, whether before or after the relevant Exit Transfer Date, to make a change which amounts or would amount to a repudiatory breach of contract of employment of any Potential Exit Transferring Employee, or is or would be a substantial change in working conditions to the material detriment of that employee as provided for by the Transfer Regulations.

Schedule 9

IT and IT Specification / Interface Specification

Introduction

This schedule describesABC IT requirements for the Services.ABC core business solutions are delivered by a SAP installation ("ABCSAP System").

This schedule details specific requirements for provision of the IT systems for management of the Services by the Contractor (WMS Warehouse Management System).

The WMS must meet allABCspecific requirements where listed below.

The WMS will offer flexibility for future development to support any new requirements that may arise during the contract period.

The WMS must successfully interface toABCSAP System, and the interfaces function quickly and without error. The frequency of message sharing in queues either side of the interface should never mean a single message waiting in excess of 15 minutes.

The interfaces required (as a minimum) are listed within this Schedule.

AWarehouse Process and Operational Requirements

The following outlines the functions that the Contractor shall provide for an RF enabled Warehouse Management System (WMS)

  1. GOODS RECEIPT

Receive Advanced Shipment Notification (See Interfaces below)

Scan (or create and scan) label to confirm receipt

Certain SKUs flagged as QC quarantine status by default on inbound, for later QC release

Ability to receive returns and direct to returns area under quarantine status where required

Some goods will require palletisation / labelling - Handling Unit (SSCC) label printing toABC' specification required (able to be used directly by customers andABCsites)

PUT-AWAY / STORAGE

Assign put-away location per pallet based on criteria to be agreed e.g. proximity to pick-face, technical segregation rules

Put-away confirmed byUU and location scan to ensure accuracy

Confirmation of receipt toKLatUUlevel

PICK-FACE REPLENISHMENTS

Pick-face replenishments to be automatically generated based on criteria to be defined e.g. orders in pipeline, trigger point, replenish up-to level etc.

Stock rotation by shortest BBE combined with customer-specific BBE rules

To manage the multiple life requirements at customers multiple pick-faces are required for materials to allow selection of correct life. Remaining life must be defined based on delivery date not pick date.

Ability to maintain and replenish multiple pick-faces per SKU where required to reflect multiple BBE criteria

Scan pallet label / location to confirm movement

Confirmation toABCSAP System atUUlevel of drops and any moves back.

FULL PALLET PICKING

Select based on shortest BBE combined with customer-specific BBE rules and delivery status requirements clearance of part pallets to be considered.

Scan pallet label / location to confirm movement

Transit to marshalling area and scan to marshalling lane

Confirmation toABCSAP System atUUlevel

PART PALLET / CASE PICKING

Soft allocation of stock according to shortest BBE combined with customer-specific BBE rules and delivery status requirements.

WMS directs picker to correct location according to rotation / specific BBE requirement

Picker to scan location to confirm pick

Real-time update of stock position / status

Confirmation toABCSAP System at newUUlevel

Customer specific stack and presentation requirements will need to be met.

MARSHALLING AND LOADING / DESPATCH

WMS to manage load to marshalling lane allocation

Scan to confirm arrival of picked pallets at marshalling lane

WMS to direct loading when complete load is marshalled

WMS to direct correct order of loading e.g. first drop last for multiple drops

WMS to direct loading at pallet level to enable combined deliveries according to stacking rules only certain products can act as a'base and only certain products can be stacked on top (according to weight)

Scan to confirm pallets loaded to vehicle

Outbound Delivery assembly and Shipment/Load collection times are subject to change and after the initial send hauliers will advise via interfaces of changes to required assembly times and collection times WMS to manage this with necessary notification triggers where assembly has already started

Confirmation toABCSAP System atUUlevel

Delivery Note (use of pro-forma, multi-copy & dot matrix with varying customer requirements as to content) printing and Uplift Notes as perABC requirements

TRACEABILITY

Full handling Unit & Batch traceability must be provided at all process stages

RETURNS PROCESS

Receipt of returns from inbound into returns area

Post inspection / re-package update status and return good stock to existing same-sku occupied or empty locations according to BBE

Confirm toABCSAP System atUUlevel

PERPETUAL INVENTORY CHECKING

Management of a schedule (which shall comply with the RFQ issued byABC(dated 30 March 2016) for full requirements) of pick-face checking (may be partially or wholly integrated with picking process), empty location checking and cycle counting of warehouse locations

Scan product, location and confirm quantity

Real-time adjustment of physical stock

Advice toABCSAP System atUUlevel

LABOUR MANAGEMENT

WMS to manage efficient allocation of tasks to minimise travel and maximise productivity

WMS to collect and hold data to enable performance analysis, e.g. colleagues to be'logged in to a particular activity, individual tasks to be retained by colleague for a reasonable period to be agreed

REPORTING AND ENQUIRIES

XYZLogistics have won a contract with **** to run a warehouse in ****. This document has been compiled based on details known as at000000.

Purpose of Document

To ensure that IT business continuity planning has been prepared for and agreed to prior to IT systems going live and in the event of a system failure, the business / operations management are aware of what they would need to do to resolve system issues and thus recover effectively and promptly.

Appendix 1 Disaster Recovery Process of All Entities That Are Viewed to be Key to the *** contract (ie IT entities listed in section (3) as having a CRITICAL business impact if they failed)

  1. ENTITY FAILED DLX WMS

Fallback process:Revert to mirrored infrastructure (once failure reason has been determined/ resolution ETA has been determined). The time to revert to the mirrored infrastructure will be subject to what has failed and is normally only done when the issue is viewed to be significant / will take a long time to resolve. Once the identified issue has been resolved then for a period of time there would be additional system outages to facilitate reverting back to the original IT/ DLX architecture. The time to revert to the mirrored infrastructure could be as little as 2 hours though could be circa 8 hours as will depend on what has failed / what order each DLX environment is setup on the mirrored infrastructure.

Fault reporting process:CallXYZIT service desk.

Re-alignment process:There should be no data loss as data is mirrored in real time thus no work to re-align the system should be necessary.

ENTITY FAILED RF NETWORK FAILURE (IE TOTAL FAILURE OF BOTH RF CONTROLLERS AT THE SAME TIME)

Fallback process:Replace faulty equipment asap. This could potentially be done the same working day. If error happened at a weekend / out of hours then would be best endeavours to repair asap.

Fault reporting process:CallXYZIT service desk.

Re-alignment process: None of any note.

ENTITY FAILED INTERFACE FILE PROCESSING FAILURE (IE MQ FAILURE)

Fallback process:Revert to backup IT infrastructure. This could be done within a few hours of the error being identified.

Fault reporting process:CallXYZIT service desk.

Re-alignment process:There may be a requirement for the customer (ie ***) to resubmit files where files were on the server at the point in time that the server failed.

SECTION 1 - SUMMARY OF SITE DETAILS

Section 2 - General Description Of The Premises
NDC is situated on a business park situated within 1 mile of the M1. The warehouse is 22800 sq. ft. and office accommodation. The contract began on site on February 1st, 2012 providing warehouse and logistics for DEF UK. To the front of the unit is an office block, two storeys of which the majority of the first floor is open plan. The ground floor consists of smaller office areas together with toilet and locker room facilities and a canteen area which is operated by Sodexo. The warehouse area consists of predominantly floor storage, but there is a small section of racking towards one corner. The plant room is located to the top of the building and is maintained and monitored by Sodexo. To the front of the warehouse there is a canopy area where the loading/unload of HGV takes place. There is a regular flow of MHE through all the bay doors to this canopy area. The site operates both diesel and gas powered MHE. There are two diesel storage tanks on site, 1 for on road diesel and the other for off road diesel (shunter and MHE). There is a separate storage tank for ADblue. There is also storage for the gas bottles. These are stored in separate cages, one for full and one for empty. The site has 24 hour security and CCTV operation. The area is surrounded with an electrically charged, monitored fence. This is monitored by the 24 hour security. The site has one main access/egress, but is sub divided to HGV vehicles having an entrance to the yard area to the right and other traffic with an entrance to the left. Access is controlled with fobs issued to colleagues and an intercom system via security for visitors and contractors.

schedule 14

Warehouse Rules

ABCand its employees, agents and subcontractors shall be entitled to access to the Principal Warehouse(including full unfettered access of the office facilities)provided thatABCcomplies with the following rules:

  1. It provides reasonable advance notice to the Contractor;

It complies with the reasonable health and safety requirements of the Contractor (including in relation to PPE);

Employees ofABCare escortedonto the premises(but no escort needed for access to the nominated office space.

schedule 15

Continuous Improvement

INTRODUCTION

  1. The Contractor andABCagree that a shared objective of the parties is to frequently review the Services and Charges to identify how Charges can potentially be reduced, and quality of Services can be improved.

Therefore both parties shall establish an Innovation Board which is used to identify potential areas for review, make proposals to improve Services and/or reduce Charges and see through to implementation.

This Schedule establishes the process for review, proposals to improve Services and/or reduce Charges, to subsequently vary this Agreement and to share the financial benefits of such changes.

This Schedule applies to the services provided pursuant to this Agreement and also the Transport Agreement, and therefore references in this Schedule to"Services"relates to Services provided under this Agreement and also the Transport Agreement and references to"Charges"relates to Charges provided under this Agreement and also the Transport Agreement. Should this Agreement or the Transport Agreement terminate this Schedule deals with the subsequent change.

Savings relating totheTownServices (as set out in Schedule 17 of this Agreement) and the transport services that the Contractor may (if the parties agree) carry out pursuant to Schedule 21 of the Transport Agreement (TownTransport Services) are subject to a separate gainshare mechanism as referred to in Part 8 of Schedule 17 (TownServices) and Schedule 21 of the Transport Agreement, respectively).This Schedule applies to Savings and Gainshare achieved on or after the FullService Commencement Date. The parties may agree in writing gainshare arrangements relating to Transition Services (if not already included in Schedule 8 (Transition Services) and any Savings and Gainshare achieved before the Full Service Commencement Date will count towards the Savings of the first Budget Year governed by this Schedule, save as set out above in respect ofTown(albeit that the Contractor shall be entitled to introduce similar initiatives as those introduced in respect ofTownunder the mechanism in this Schedule).

INNOVATION BOARD AND CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT REGISTER

The table below sets out the members of the Innovation Board. The Innovation Board shall meet as set out at Schedule4 (Contract Management, Information & Reporting). The provisions of Schedule4shall apply to this Schedule unless stated otherwise in this Schedule.

At the first meeting of the Innovation Board pursuant to Schedule 4 the parties shall compile a Continuous Improvement Register setting out proposals for Service improvement and reducing Charges. The Continuous Improvement Register shall identify the relevant initiative, the key actions of each party, its status, (once agreed between the parties) a record of the method of calculating savings or income generation, and amount actually saved or income generated.

The Innovation Board shall at each meeting review and update the Continuous Improvement Register.

The status of each initiative shall track its development as a proposal:

Potential are for consideration subject to nominated party developing a business plan

Business plan submitted but not yet agreed as a proposal

Business plan agreed including method of calculating saving/income generation

Business plan being implemented

Business plan fully implemented, initiative under review to identify actual savings/income generation

Initiatives which are visible to or have an impact on the interface and relationship withABCcustomers are reviewed and agreed upon by the Innovation Board as a separate item, all parties recognising the need for these to be dealt with especially sensitively.

The parties will use reasonable endeavours to agree and then support continuous improvement initiatives and shall fulfil the obligations that each agrees to as recorded in the Continuous Improvement Register.

Any dispute or failure to agree by the Innovation Board shall be referred to the monthly meeting referred to at Schedule4.

CALCULATION OF GAINSHARE

  1. The parties agree that where there is in a Budget Year a SavingABCshall share the Gainshare for that Saving with the Contractor subject to the following:

ABCobligation to pay the Contractor Gainshare in relation to a Saving is only for the 12 month period from the commencement of the initiative. All Savings following that 12 month period is exclusively forABC.

The calculation of Saving is by reference to actual saving realised or actual income received byABC

The expansion of scope or volume of the Services under this Agreement or the Transport Agreement shall be excluded from being eligible for calculation of Savings and the Gainshare. However once the additional services have become established then they are subject to Continuous Improvement and eligible for Savings and Gainshare;

All Savings shall be calculated net of cost to achieve such Saving

If there is any Gainshare in any Budget Year,ABCshall pay it to the Contractor within 60 days of the end of that Budget Year (and receipt of the Contractors invoice)

Part 3- Service Levels

The Contractor shall perform theTownServices in accordance with the Service Levels set out in Annex 3 to this Schedule 17.

Part 4- Charges

  1. The Charges for theTownServices shall be calculated in accordance with Schedule 2 (Charges) save that:

no management fee shall be payable in respect of theTownServices;

the following provisions shall not apply:

all provisions in relation, and references, to the"Management Fee", including the definition of"Management Fee", paragraph 2.1.1,

Part 7 (Dilapidations);

Part 8 (Capital Investment in the Principal Warehouse;

Part 9 (Other); and

all references to the"Annual Budget"shall, for the purposes of theTownServices, be the budget annexed at Annex 4 to this Schedule 17 ("TownBudget").

The parties acknowledge and agree that they shall each cooperate in good faith and use all reasonable endeavours to agree which party shall manage which elements of theTownBudget save that the parties agree thatthe Contractor shall, asa minimum, manage the labour costs.

TheContractoragrees that it shall use theTransferring Employeesand, to the extentpossible, bearing in mind the existing terms and conditions of the Transferring Employees, will manage the notice periods of the Transferring Employees so as to mitigate the expected000,000PILON liability to the fullest extent possible, and the Contractor shall only request reimbursement of the Transferring Employee Termination Liabilities referred to within this paragraph 3 of thisPart 4 ofSchedule 17 fromABConce they have exceeded000,000.Forthe avoidance of doubt any request for reimbursement made in accordance with this paragraph shall remain subject to paragraph 4.1 of Schedule 7(Employment Provisions).

Part 5- Property Licence

ABCshall grant the Contractor a licence to use and accessTownsitesin the formsset out in Annex 1A and Bto this Schedule 17(the areas licensed pursuant to such licencesto becollectivelyknown as the"TownSite").

The Contractor shall ensure that theTownSites are operated in accordance with the Global Standard, the BRC Standard and the H&S Standards.

Part 6- Access toABCSystems

In this Part 6 the following definitions shall apply:

"ABCSystems"the IT/ software warehouse management system belonging to or used by or on behalf ofABCwhich includes theABCSAP systems and relevant to the provision of theTownServices and utilised at theTownSite as at the date of this Agreement.

  1. ABChereby grants to the Contractor the right to access and use theABCSystems during theTownServices Period solely and exclusively for the purposes of performing theTownServices.

The Contractor shall only be entitled to use theABCSystems in accordance withABC' instructions and in order to fulfil its obligations under this Agreement to perform theTownServices, and that use shall be non-exclusive, non-transferable, and subject to any other termsABCmay specify. In addition, whereABCprovides the Contractor with access to any software or materials licensed toABCby a third party, the Contractor must comply with the licence terms imposed by that third party ("Third Party Licence Terms").ABCwill notify these terms to the Contractor on request.

The Contractor shall fully and effectively indemnify and hold harmlessABCGroup Companies against all losses, actions, costs (including legal fees and disbursements on a solicitor/client basis), claims, demands, fines, damages and liabilities, of whatever nature, incurred or suffered by or made against any of them, whether or not foreseeable, arising directly or indirectly, wholly or in part, out of or in connection with any breach by the Contractor of any Third Party Licence Terms.

PART 7- FUTURE USE OF THETOWNSITE

  1. The Contractor shall use all reasonable endeavours to secure a future use of theTownSite (including using within the Contractor's own warehouse network, or use by a customer of the Contractor) and topostpone or mitigatethe EmploymentLiabilitiesthat may arise on ceasing to provide theTownServices.

The Contractor shall report to and consult withABCon at least a monthly basis at the monthly meetings referred to in Schedule 4 (Contract Management Information and Reporting) on the efforts it is making and opportunities identified. The Contractor shall take reasonable heed ofABC' comments, suggestions and leads.

If the Contractor identifies an opportunity for the future use of theTownSite then it will notifyABCin writing setting out the opportunity, the costs to secure that opportunity and how that compares with the cost toABCof closing theTownSite.

The parties agree that the gainshare mechanism as set out in Schedule 15 (Continuous Improvement) of this Agreement shall apply as a separate mechanism in relation to theTownServices save thatparagraphs14 to 23 (inclusive) of such Schedule shall not apply.

Annex 2

TOWNSERVICES

WAREHOUSE OPERATIONAL SPECIFICATION

The activities listed below are included as part of the warehouse solution atTownforABC.

The Contractor's performance will be monitored on a continual basis against agreed performance measures. In additionABCreserves the right to monitor the Contractor's performance against any of the warehousing requirements and standards listed below.

  1. WAREHOUSE REQUIREMENTS

TheTownWarehouseis as provided byABC.TownSite has both vehicle and personnel security control drivers are required to carry photo ID

OPERATING REQUIREMENTS

The operating requirements are defined by a combination ofABCSBU requirement,ABC' customer order requirements and the need to minimise the operating costs incurred in the warehouse operation.

StandardsThe Contractor shall ensure that it performs theTownServices in accordance with:

The Policies

The Global Standards

The BRC Standard

TheABCHealth and Safety Procedures Sections 4.3, 1.6, General Rules and Conditions for Contractors (Revision 3) (as updated from time to time) ("H&S Standard")

Health and Safety Executive Warehousing and Storage, A guide to health and safety (HSG76 (as updated from time to time) ("HSE Guidance").

ABCCode of Practice- Finished Goods Case and Pallet Standard (CoP060) ("Case and Pallet Standard").

The operation will be audited against legal standards as well as the Global Standard, in particular with reference to segregation, hygiene and traceability rules.

The Contractor shall work withABCto adhere to the required Supply Chain Security requirements required byABCand notified to the Contractor for all the markets in whichABCoperates, both local and international.

The Contractor shall (and shall procure that all sub-contractors shall) co-operate fully and promptly with the transport provider and all other third party service providers ofABCin relation to all activities relating to this Agreement and any points of interoperability or dependency between theTownServices and the services to be provided by the transport provider and/or such third party service providers.

TYPES OF PRODUCT

Product will arrive on pallets and in case multiples or in containers in loose form. Pallets will be a variety of heights.The Contractor will be required to deal with a variety of pallets includingstandard Chep blue pallets, euro pallets, dollies and white export pallets. All pallets fromABCfactories will be labelled, some pallets from Bought-In- Finished Goods (BIFG) providers will be labelled and some will need to be labelled by the Contractor upon receipt. The Contractor shall label cases and pallets in accordance with the Case and Pallet Standard, the example labels set out in Appendix 2 to this Schedule and any other requirements ofABCnotified to Contractor from time to time.

Pallet heights and weights will range in accordance withABCrequirements. As at the date of the Agreement the pallet heights range from 1.0M to 1.5M and weights range up to 500kg. Individual case weight ranges from 0.5kg to 7kg. These requirements may vary in accordance withABC' requirements as notified byABCto Contractor from time to time. All Products are ambient food grade products in boxes and point of sales displays (POS).

CONTRACTOR'S SYSTEM

ABCuses SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system. The Contractor shall use theABCSAP warehouse management system (WMS) ("Customer SAP WMS") subject to and in accordance with Part 6 of this Schedule 17 above, that can provide:

Stock management of Products in theTownWarehouse or otherwise in the possession of the Contractor

Total product traceability

Drive all operational activities in theTownWarehouse

Interface withABCchosen transport provider (as notified byABCto Contractor from time to time).

The Contractor shall manage stocks of Product in the Customer SAP WMS from the point of receipt by the Contractor in the Customers SAP WMS.The Contractor shall comply with the requirements set out in Schedule 9 (IT and IT Specification/ Interface Specification).

VOLUME FORECASTING

As part of the annual budgeting process set out in Schedule 2 (The Charges)ABCwill provide the Contractor with an annualised view ofABC' storage and throughput requirements, which will be reviewed and updated periodically in line with business change. A 6 weekly forecast will be provided by the customer weekly to the contractor (for the next 6 week period), this forecast will provide dailyABCCustomer case volumes however will be subject to actual daily movement.

ORDER MANAGEMENT - INBOUND FROM FACTORY AND BIFG

ABCwill provide the Contractor with an estimate of the number of pallets / loads from factories to be delivered toTownWarehouse. Lead time will vary from Day1 for Day1 to Day1 for Day 2.

Bought In Finished Goods suppliers are accommodated on varying lead times.

GOODS IN AND CHECKING

The Contractor shall be required to manage the inbound vehicle schedule for all inbound deliveries.

Depending on the delivery type (single and double deck, double deck fixed and moving floor, box and curtain side,) Product will arrive through a bay door or dock and the ability to unload from the side or through the rear shall be required.

The Contractor shall be responsible for the unloading and receipt of Product.

This function includes the unloading of single deck, double deck, curtain-siders, using a variety of equipment to an inbound marshalling area.

Quality checks shall be made by Contractor as part of the unloading process (to ensure that Product is not damaged and corresponds to the ASN and manifest paperwork referred to above). Such checks shall include any checks required in the Global Standard and the following minimum checksASN correctly booked in, product booked in corresponds with the ASN paperwork, checking pallet ID, item code, BBE, batch, quantity, EAN, missing pallet, over-allocated pallets, taints, foreign bodies, pest and contamination that can be identified visually at pallet level. An exceptions report shall be prepared by Contractors on the inbound quality check form approved byABCand shall be issued toABCvia email immediately (and at the latest within 24 hours of the load arrival). If there is a problem with any Product, this Product will be segregated by the Contractor into a separate area until a decision is reached as to what action to take.

Product shall be confirmed by the Contractor as receipted into theTownWarehouse usingABC' RF scanners and the Customer SAP WMS and BIFG pallets shall be blind checked at cases quantity, and labelled by the Contractor in readiness for putaway.

Details provided in the ASN will be confirmed thus establishing a record of batch and expiry date where relevant. 1 single SKU / batch combination per pallet received.

PUTAWAY

Once pallets have been checked and confirmed onto the system, the adjustable pallet racking (APR) section. This is controlled by the Customer SAP WMS using segregation, zoning and any segregation/constraint rules as set out in the Global Standard and in order to optimise efficiency of theTownServices.

Under standard operations, all Product shall be put away into reserve locations. However, should there be a requirement to cross-dock Product through theTownWarehouse as a result of any late production necessitating product to be immediately despatched from theTownWarehouse the Contractor shall fulfil such requirement. This is estimated as <0% of Sweet Treats volume.

The Customer SAP WMS shall determine the optimum location for the pallet to be stored, taking into account the restrictions of pallet height and weight. The putaway shall be confirmed using RF scanners, by firstly scanning the pallet ID followed by the racking location bar code. A level of manual intervention will be required from the Contractor in order to manage putaway strategy.

STORAGE

The Contractor shall:

Ensure stock location integrity within theTownWarehouse.

Recover and make good"pallet falls", whilst in their custody.- Ensure that housekeeping is maintained in line with the processes set out in the Global Standard and BRC Standard.

All internal movements of pallets for housekeeping or storage efficiency purpose are to be recorded on the Customer SAP WMS.

REPLENISHMENT

Replenishment of pallets should only occur for case picked volume. Pallets shall be moved from APR racking reserve locations to replenish the case pick locations within the APR racking. The replenishment activity includes having to add any residual cases onto the pallet, removing any shrinkwrap or other packaging material, and removing the old pallet from the pickface.

ORDER MANAGEMENT - OUTBOUND FROM WAREHOUSE

The Contractor must ensure the order is picked in time to meet the scheduled collection time for the load as set out on the transport dispatch schedule.

ABCwill provide as much visibility as it is able to, to ensure orders are completed, however, if stock of Product is due to be received to meet an order the Contractor will be required to wait until the latest possible time that day that the Contractor can start picking in order to ensure maximum order fill before the planned despatch time before commencing picking of orders to maximise the availability of stock.

PICK

The pick will be either full pallet pick or case pick and the principle of'first in, first out will be adopted unlessABC' customer agreed specific requirements require otherwise.ABCwill send to the Contractor, within the sales order, the minimum age requirement (i.e.the minimum best before end date on the Product to be sent to theABC' customer as defined on the order) that theABC' customer will accept and any specific requirements or instructions relating to that customer. The Contractor shall fulfil the order with the oldest Product stock in the warehouse that meets the customer requirement. This process will be managed by the contractor within the Customer SAP WMS.

Full pallet pick will be carried out within the standard APR racking reserve locations. The pick itself will be confirmed to the WMS using RF scanners.

Case picking will be done at ground level within the standard APR racking area using appropriate equipment. The Contractor will be required to comply with any special instructions of aABCcustomer to provide Product on a single Product per pallet basis.

An efficient walk sequence which reduces any potential Product damage by engaging a heavy-to-light profile shall be created and used by the Contractor. This will be regularly reviewed by the Contractor throughout the contract term to ensure Good Industry Practice and optimum Product allocation in the case picking area.

All picks shall be controlled through the Customers SAP WMS thus maintaining appropriate traceability of Product through all associated activities.

A number of dynamic pick locations based on RFQ levels will be created to handle any sudden demand changes and the requirement for different Best-Before-End's (BBEs) by customer to the SKUs picked at case level.

The Contractor shall generate an exceptions report which details any shortages (e.g.as a result of a Product on an order than cannot be loaded) and provide such report toABCas soon as practicable.Any shortages will be investigated by the Contractors' stock team to firstly understand the issue, and to try and resolve the problem.

MARSHALLING AND LOADING

All picked volume of Product shall be marshalled and checked within the outbound marshalling area. If any Product is to be sent overseas the Contractor shall, where required byABCbe responsible for sealing the relevant containers and recording such seals.

Product which has been picked at case level will be securely stretch wrapped and labelled in readiness for loading in accordance with the Global Standard and Good Industry Practice andABCcustomer requirements. Case picked pallets require a single handling label detailing quantity by sku as set out in the example in Appendix 2 to this Schedule.

Loading will be onto a mix of single deck, double deck, curtain-siders or 20ft and 40ft containers using appropriate equipment. Pallets will be confirmed as loaded onto the Customers WMS and need to be scanned individually onto the trailer.

There are a mix of live loading and stand trailers. Depending on the trailer type, Product shall be loaded through a bay door or a dock.

A shunt vehicle and driver shall be available to move any trailers on/off docks and bays as required. Note that it is the hauliers responsibility to ensure that vehicle loads are strapped adequately safe and reach their destination in the expected quality. The Contractor is responsible for loading Product and providing access to straps. The Contractor shall load Product in accordance with the Global Standard and HSE Guidance and shall ensure that the process of loading does not compromise the security of the Product or the vehicle or the weight of distribution of the loads. If the transport vehicle is to carry multiple deliveries of Product the Contractor shall ensure the Products are loaded so that they can be unloaded efficiently in accordance with the transport dispatch schedule.

INDIRECT ACTIVITIES

The Contractor shall also be responsible for a number of other indirect activities to support the main activities listed above. These functions include staff briefings, warehouse cleaning and hygiene, returns management and product reconfiguration (recoup management), pallet sortation (which the Contractor shall carry out in accordance with the Case and Pallet Standard), product sampling, samples order picking and packing and training. The Contractor shall carry out such activities in accordance with the Global Standards and anyABCinstructions notified byABCto the Contractor from time to time.

STOCK MANAGEMENT

Product shall normally be selected for pick based on remaining shelf life, and against customer specific requirements. However, whereABCinstructs otherwise, stock may also have to be selected based on other criteria such as return of specific batches or particularly short-dated stock.

Stock of Product will be counted on a perpetual cycle, all locations to be counted four times in a twelve month period. There shall be a regime of more specific checks including empty slot checks, location accuracy checks, regular and frequent pick face checks and checks of dynamic locations.

The Contractor shall establish the root cause of any Product stock inaccuracies whether related to IT systems, processes or human error.

Stock management shall be reported toABCas follows:

Gross / net stock adjustments by reason per Accounting Period

Damage in warehouse by reason with trends per Accounting Period

Location accuracy Weekly

Empty slot accuracy Weekly

Returns volume / reason Weekly

Any stock issues that may have a financial or service implication shall be brought by the Contractor to the attention ofABCimmediately.

PEAK MANAGEMENT

During peak periods, it is envisaged that the stock holding capacity of theTownWarehouse could be exceeded. The Contractor will be responsible for managing any overflow requirement in a mutually agreed location to the same standards as are required at theTownWarehouse (unless otherwise agreed withABC). This shall include the transfer of relevant stock and appropriate stock management, hygiene, operations management and control to a level agreed byABC

Overall stock visibility will be managed within Customer SAP WMS by the Contractor.

RETURNS

The objective of any returns process is to ensure good Product stock is received and processed as quickly as possible (within 8 hours) and returned to stockholding to limit any mis-rotation and subsequent loss toABC.

If despatched Product is to be returned to theTownWarehouse, resulting from a collection order place byABC, thenABCshall advise the Contractor in advance in writing andABCshall instruct the appropriate haulier accordingly.

Upon receipt, instructions are to be taken fromABCregarding the intended disposition of such stock based on known quality criteria and in accordance with the Global Standard.

Appropriate action shall then be taken by the Contractor based onABC' instructions.

For any Product returns resulting from customer refusals, rejections or POD corrections, then the haulier shall liaise directly with the Contractor to ensure timely notification of return of that stock. The Contractor shall adviseABCof such customer refusal, rejection or POD correction andABCwho shall give instruction to the Contractor in relation to the treatment of such stock.

HEALTH & SAFETY

The Contractor shall at all times carry out its operations in such a way as to comply with its obligations and duties under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 as a minimum and as detailed in their health and safety statements.

The Contractor shall maintain a record of every incident relevant to safety, occurring whether or not the same results in personal injury or damage to property and shall provideABC, on request, with access to such records for inspection purposes. The Contractor shall submit a written report of any accident or dangerous occurrence as is required by law to provide to the relevant authority and shall promptly provide a copy of such report toABCwhere reasonably required.

The Contractor shall carry out safety audits on a regular basis against all operational and documented procedures. These audits must be carried out by approved and qualified personnel.

The Contractor shall comply with the H&S Standard and the HSE Guidance.

The Contractor shall be responsible for the management of Health and Safety at theTownSite and shall carry out this obligation in accordance with all Applicable Law.

Risk Assessments

Risk Assessments shall be completed by a competent person(s) on all the Contractor tasks that are considered to be a potential hazard. A safe system of working (SSW") shall be completed for each task that has been risk assessed. Once completed the SSW shall be communicated to all relevant personnel and be signed off and dated by the developer of the SSW and all personnel who will be undertaking the tasks.

Manual Handling Guidelines

The Contractor shall ensure that all manual handling that will be carried out on site should be risk assessed by a competent person(s). A risk management plan shall be compiled by the Contractor based on the findings where the highest risks are prioritised for action with the emphasis on whoever controls the relevant operation owning the risk assessment.

The Contractor shall ensure that all risk assessments should be kept on file and should be made available toABC, on request, for audit purposes.

Training

The Contractor shall ensure that all its employees, workers and sub-contractors are fully trained and competent to complete the task(s) they are required to do and provide theTownServices. The Contractor shall ensure that all training must be completed by a competent person(s). Full training records will be kept up to date and be signed and dated by the trainee and the trainer or a responsible manager.

It is the responsibility of the Contractor to ensure that training and development contributes to the effectiveness of its operations, and to provide opportunities for the individual employee to develop his/her talents within the manpower needs of the business. This will be achieved by the Contractor:

Ensuring that all employees are fully aware of the structure and activities of the Contractor and of their relationship withABC

Providing training to a level which ensures efficient performance of the job for which each employee is recruited and thereafter to help him/her to realise his/her full potential, as far as is consistent with the needs of the business.

Promoting and teaching methods of working which ensure that satisfactory standards of health, safety and welfare are maintained.

Induction Policy

The Contractor shall ensure that a site safety policy will be in place for visitors and sub-contractors, a copy of which will be provided by the Contractor toABCupon request.

Management Qualifications Requirements

The Contractor shall have a manager responsible for health and safety who holds a relevant, recognised qualification. They must be aware of safety legislation, risk awareness, risk management, risk assessment, accident investigation & safe working procedures. This manager should be suitably qualified and trained.

Near Miss Recording

The Contractor shall ensure that all near misses must be recorded on a near miss/incident form. Once completed, the form must be handed in to a manager in the area where the incident took place.

Trend Analysis

The Contractor shall collate all data relating to environmental, health & safety incidents and shall make such data available to be reviewed byABC.

Fire safety

The Contractor shall comply fully with the requirements of all the appropriate site fire safety policies.

ENVIRONMENT & QUALITY

The Contractor shall comply fully with the requirements of all the appropriate site environmental and quality policies.

FOOD & HYGIENE STANDARDS

ABCoperates full traceability of inventory from manufacturing to delivery point location.Provided that the current processes andABC systems allow for it, the Contractor shall comply withABCquality standards for traceability and quality controls in accordance with the Global Standard.

FOOD LEGISLATION COMPLIANCE

The Contractor shall ensure that its facilities, vehicles and management of its operational practices shall comply with the requirements of Applicable Law relating to food safety.

REPORTING

Provided that the necessary reports can be accessed from the Customer SAP WMS or other systems run by the Contractor, the Contractor shall provide a range of management information and reports on a daily, weekly, periodical and annual basis. These shall include information on health & safety, operational performance, service performance, stock, finance and continuous improvement and the following specific information

Health & Safety RIDDORS, lost time incidents per 100,000 labour hours, other accidents and incidents

Operational pick accuracy, on-time despatch, on-time delivery, OTIF performance, damages, progress against audit results, MHE performance

Inventory Perpetual Inventory (PI) status adjustments and accuracy, returns tracking, customer claims

Financial split by business unit, adherence to operating budget and flex budget and management of variances, productivity tracking, CI performance, utility costs

HR review of headcount, absence, staff turnover, disciplinary issues

The Contractor will be required to meet or exceed the Service Levels and performance against these levels will be monitored and communicated.

RECORDS

The Contractor shall keep records of all reports required under this Schedule for a minimum of 7 years from the date of their creation.

SECURITY

Site security arrangements will beprovided and managed byABCanddeployed as per guidelines set out in the Global Standard, and as agreed with theABCproject implementation team. This includes adequate control of visitors to the site.

Security of vehicle loads outside of the perimeter of theTownWarehouse, either inbound or outbound, is not within the scope of this operational specification.

DAMAGES

All damages whether identified at the point of unloading (Goods In), or damages incurred whilst in the custody and control of the Contractors shall be recorded (where possible including photographs) and reported toABC. Such damages will be segregated into a separate area until a decision is reached as to what action to take.

SITE MAINTENANCE

The Contractor shall be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of theTownSites provided thatABCshall be responsible for the reasonable costs of materials and third party servicesin connection with such maintenance and upkeep.

OPERATING HOURS

TheTownWarehouse shall operate twenty four hours per day, seven days per week if required but excluding

Christmas Day; and

New Years Day

Bank holidays (excluding Christmas Day and New Years Day) are assumed to be normal working days.

For Christmas Day and New Years Day arrangements will be discussed and agreed withABCand will be based upon customer requirements but the Contractor will be expected to provide a minimum level of cover as follows:

Christmas Eve / New Years Eve open until 22:00

Boxing Day / New Years Day re-open 10:00

Annex 3 (to schedule 17)

Service Levels (Town)

In this Annex the following words and expressions have the following meanings:

Accounting Periodhas the meaning given in Schedule 2 (Charges).
Minimum Performance Levelmeans in relation to each Service Level the minimum level of performance required (expressed as a %) in the column "Minimum Performance Level" in Table 1 of this Annex (as applicable)
First Tier Service Levelmeans the Service Levels set out in Section 1 of this Annex.
Second Tier Service Levelmeans the Service Levels set out in Section 2 of this Annex.
Targetmeans, in relation to a Service Level, the level of performance set out in the column "Target (%) per Accounting Period" in Table 1, Table 2 or Table 3 of this Annex (as applicable).
Termination Thresholdmeans, in respect of Service Levels 1 to 3 (inclusive) failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in respect of a Service Level three (3) times or more in any rolling six (6) consecutive Accounting Periods.
  1. SERVICE LEVELS

This Annex sets out the Service Levels in relation to theTownServices to be provided by the Contractor toABC. First Tier Service Levels are set out in Section 1 of this Annex and Second Tier Service Levels are set out in Section 2 of this Annex.

SERVICE LEVEL MANAGEMENT AND REPORTING PROCESS

All Service Levels detailed in this Annex shall be measured, reported and reviewed on a continuous basis and in accordance with this Annex and Schedule4(Contract Management, Information and Reporting). A consolidated performance measure for each Service Level shall be calculated and reported toABCby Contractor for each week, each Accounting Period and each Budget Year.

If any of the Service Levels fall below the Minimum Performance Level (in addition to the requirements set out in Clause 6 of the Agreement) or in relation to the Second Tier Service Levels, the Target, meetings shall be convened between representatives of the parties to identify the root cause, identify an action plan and agree timescales to remedy as follows:

1 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling periodeach parties' Account Director;

2 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling periodeach parties' Regional Director;

3 x failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level in any 6 month rolling periodeach parties' Head of Procurement and a senior executive

SERVICE FAILURE

Failure to meet the Minimum Performance Level for any First Tier Service Level in any Accounting Period will be dealt with in accordance with Clause 6.3of this Agreement and paragraphs 3 b)to 3c) (inclusive) below.

If the Termination Threshold is reached in respect of a First Tier Service Level this shall constitute a"Material Service Level Breach"andABCshall be entitled to terminate theTownServices.

Failure to meet the Target for any Second Tier Service Level in any Accounting Period will be dealt with in accordance with Section 2 of this Annex.

SERVICE LEVEL #1 FULL PALLET ORDER ACCURACY

  1. MEASURE

The number of full pallets not in error wrong product sent, pallet missed on despatch, pallet not received byABC' customer, as a percentage of full pallets despatched.

PURPOSE

To monitor the effectiveness of the Contractor in meeting the requirements ofABC customers, to ensure high attainment to despatch accuracy is maintained.

TARGET

Full pallet load accuracy0% of all despatched loads

MINIMUM PERFORMANCE LEVEL

0% full pallet load accuracy of all despatched loads.

MEANS OF MEASUREMENT

The volume of pallets despatched will be verified between the Contractor Systems and theABC Systems. If there is a discrepancy between the two systems, the Contractor shall investigate and report on the cause of discrepancy and the parties shall use reasonable endeavours to resolve the discrepancy. If the parties cannot resolve the discrepancy,ABC' System shall prevail.

The POD information will also be used to verify load completeness atABC' customer.

FREQUENCY OF MEASUREMENT

Performance will be reviewed on a continuous basis but aggregate measurement will be appraised on an Accounting Period and cumulative year to date basis. From the Commencement Date onwards, the Contractor will formally report performance against the Target within 21 days of the end of each Accounting Period.

NON CONFORMANCE

The Contractor shall procure that a detailed corrective action report is produced immediately after any failure by the Contractor to achieve the Target during an Accounting Period.

Such corrective action report, when agreed by theABC, must immediately be actioned by the Contractor where corrective action is required as a result of its own failure to achieve the required standard.

SOURCE OF DATA

The data to be provided toABCby Contractor in a report format acceptable toABC.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR MEASUREMENT

The Contractor shall measure andABCshall verify whether the Contractor has achieved the Target using the measurements and the frequency specified above.

SERVICE LEVEL #2 Case Pick Order Accuracy

  1. MEASURE

The number of cases picked not in error wrong product sent, case missed on despatch, case not received byABC' customer- as a percentage of cases despatched.

This measure includes any case service failures incurred through:

shortages due to Contractors stock control system and processesnon-delivered shortageswrong product case delivery

Over delivery quantity

damage case delivery resulting in refusals

PURPOSE

To monitor the effectiveness of the Contractor in meeting the requirements ofABC' customers and maintaining high levels of performance.

TARGET

Case Pick accuracy greater than0% of cases despatched.

MINIMUM STANDARD / MINIMUM PERFORMANCE LEVEL

Case Pick accuracy greater than0% of cases despatched

MEANS OF MEASUREMENT
